snippet.title: Gunfire damages vehicles and home in Grand Island
snippet.description:
‚ÄúWe got a phone call from the residence at that address on 17th street," Elliot mentioned. "They heard gunshots.‚Äù

Elliott then said the victims walked outside and can‚Äôt be 100% sure if it was related, but noticed their windshields shattered and stomped on.

‚ÄúFootprints or shoeprints were seen on the dust on the vehicles and then they noticed there were gunshots or bullet holes in the vehicles, as well,‚Äù Elliott noted.

According to Elliott, the attack appeared to be targeted.

‚ÄúWe're hoping that our victims cooperate and help us to identify who our suspects are and then bring those suspects to justice,‚Äù Elliott announced.

In recent years, GIPD has committed itself to reducing crime in the city. In fact, in 2024, the crime rate dropped by just over 14% with goals of continuing to decrease that number by 15-20% in 2025 and Chief Elliott told me they were hoping for 10-15% reduction at this point in the year.

snippet.title: Huskers Wrap Up Final Practice Before Opener in Kansas City vs.Cincinnati
snippet.description:
Nebraska wrapped up its final preseason football practice in Lincoln on Tuesday before turning its focus to Thursday night‚Äôs opener against Cincinnati in Kansas City.

Head coach Matt Rhule said he is eager to man the sidelines under the bright lights.

‚ÄúThe team‚Äôs been great. I think they want to play ‚Äî it‚Äôs very evident, a very mature team,‚Äù Rhule said.

As he enters his third season in Lincoln, Rhule emphasized that he wants this year to feel different, starting with himself.

‚ÄúI very much made a commitment this year to having fun in everything that I do because it‚Äôs the type of team we have,‚Äù Rhule said.

Rhule added that the Huskers are more prepared for the opener than in past years.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre significantly further ahead in terms of how we handle a game excited to see them actually play it out,‚Äù he said.

Part of the preseason preparation included film sessions reviewing dozens of plays from last year. Rhule said the team approached it with ‚Äúhumility and accountability,‚Äù noting that too many ‚Äúbad football plays‚Äù stood out.

Ten Blackshirts were awarded this week, a tradition dating back to 1964, with the hope of turning preparation into better play on the field.

‚ÄúJust challenging the guys ‚Äî we want to go play this game one snap at a time, with intentional focus, a neutral mindset and attack each play,‚Äù Rhule said.

The Huskers will travel to Kansas City as a team on Wednesday, hold a walkthrough, meet together, and even share a movie night watching ‚ÄúSuperman‚Äù before Thursday‚Äôs 8 p.m. kickoff.

snippet.title: Nebraska Refocused After Bye Week, Rested and Ready to Face Michigan State
snippet.description:
Coming out of a bye week, Nebraska coach Matt Rhule said his team is rested, refocused, and ready to respond after a three-point loss to Michigan.

Rhule pointed to the work ethic during the off week as a sign of progress, noting players like tight end Luke Lenemeyer, who was out on the practice field doing drills on his own.

‚ÄúWe came out of the bye week feeling really good about a lot of guys in terms of where they‚Äôre at,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúI thought the team got a lot better last week.‚Äù

Nebraska (3-1, 0-1 Big Ten) will host Michigan State (3-1, 1-0) on Saturday. The Spartans are averaging more than 34 points per game behind quarterback Aidan Chiles, who has completed over 70% of his passes this season while also posing a threat as a runner.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre a pro-style offense, and he does all the pro-style things,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs taking what‚Äôs there, protecting the football. He‚Äôs one of the better quarterbacks in the Big Ten.‚Äù

Statistically, Nebraska brings one of the nation‚Äôs most explosive passing attacks, averaging 352 yards per game ‚Äî second best in the FBS. But Rhule acknowledged that the Huskers‚Äô running game and rush defense still need improvement. Nebraska is allowing 173 rushing yards per contest, which ranks outside the top 100 nationally.

On the injury front, Rhule said cornerback Malcolm Hartzog is doubtful to play. Hartzog had the game-clinching interception against Cincinnati earlier this month.

Kickoff against Michigan State is set for 3 p.m. Saturday at Memorial Stadium.

snippet.title: Top Draft Pick Caglione Prepares for Big League Outfield Role
snippet.description:
The Kansas City Royals are chasing a playoff berth and could soon get a boost from their top draft pick a year ago, Jack Caglione. But before the power-hitting prospect can join the big-league lineup, he has to master a new position ‚Äî the outfield.

Caglione, known as ‚ÄúJack Cags,‚Äù has been working on the transition this summer with the Royals' Triple-A team, the Omaha Storm Chasers. A natural infielder and pitcher, he has spent the last several weeks learning the intricacies of the outfield with the help of Royals coach Rusty Kuntz, a former big leaguer who played in the 1980s.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm pretty comfortable out there,‚Äù Caglione said. ‚ÄúThere are still some plays I‚Äôm not used to seeing. It‚Äôs a lot different than first, but that‚Äôs the learning process. Thankfully, Rusty‚Äôs out here helping me.‚Äù

The Royals value Caglione‚Äôs bat ‚Äî he has already shown home run power in Triple-A ‚Äî but need him to become dependable defensively before he makes the jump to Kansas City. Kuntz said the focus has been on fundamentals like taking proper routes and getting under control to make plays.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve got to remember that he was not an outfielder,‚Äù Kuntz said. ‚ÄúHe was an infielder and a pitcher, and now some of the things I just throw at him, I have to step back and go, ‚ÄòWait a minute, we‚Äôre still learning this process.‚Äô‚Äù

Caglione, meanwhile, is keeping a close eye on the standings.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd love to be playing in October,‚Äù he said.

Kuntz believes the young slugger has the mentality to get there.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs an absolute dream because he‚Äôs a baseball player first,‚Äù Kuntz said. ‚ÄúHe just wants to come out and compete, and he‚Äôll work his butt off. That‚Äôs a coach‚Äôs dream.‚Äù

The Royals expect Caglione to rejoin the team in September as they push toward the postseason.

snippet.title: Nebraska Ready for Michigan State After Two-Week Break
snippet.description:
The Cornhuskers have had a fortnight to stew over their loss to Michigan, but head coach Matt Rhule said his team is ready to put that behind them as they prepare to face Michigan State on Saturday.

‚ÄúThe week‚Äôs been great,‚Äù Rhule said Friday during his final press conference of the week at Memorial Stadium. ‚ÄúThey practiced hard last week. They practiced hard this week, so they‚Äôll be ready on Saturday.‚Äù

The weather could play a role in the matchup. With high winds and temperatures expected in the mid-80s, Rhule said Nebraska has been preparing for all conditions. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôll be a factor in everything that you do,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt might mean you make some different decisions than you normally would. It‚Äôs part of being in the region of the country that we‚Äôre in.‚Äù

Nebraska has not defeated Michigan State since 2018, but Rhule is confident in his team‚Äôs preparation. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm expecting our players to go play really, really well. I think they‚Äôve improved. We‚Äôre just gonna play it out and see what happens,‚Äù he said.

Kickoff against Michigan State is set for 3 p.m. Saturday at Memorial Stadium.

snippet.title: Rhule Previews Huskers vs. Michigan in Big Ten Opener
snippet.description:
Nebraska head coach Matt Rhule previewed the Huskers‚Äô first Big Ten game of the season, a home matchup Saturday against No. 21 Michigan.

The Wolverines (2-1) enter the contest without head coach Sherrone Moore, who is serving the second game of a three-game suspension for NCAA violations. Interim coach Biff Poggi, who previously coached at Charlotte, will lead Michigan after the team‚Äôs 63-3 win over Central Michigan last weekend.

The quarterback battle is expected to headline the game. Michigan will start true freshman Bryce Underwood in his first Big Ten appearance, while Nebraska (3-0) turns to sophomore second-year starter Dylan Raiola. Raiola has thrown for 829 yards, eight touchdowns, and no interceptions through three games, leading an offense that ranks fifth nationally in passing at 366 yards per game.

‚ÄúIf we have great protection ‚Äî and we‚Äôve had great protection ‚Äî then the quarterback‚Äôs going to be unbelievably efficient,‚Äù Rhule said.

Nebraska‚Äôs defense has been equally impressive, allowing just 66 passing yards per game to lead the nation. Michigan ranks 81st in passing offense at 212 yards per game and 43rd in passing defense at 182.

Rhule emphasized balance and execution as keys to Nebraska‚Äôs success. The Huskers have not had a three-and-out in the past two games but continue to focus on red-zone efficiency.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve always had a period for it, but we‚Äôll add some emphasis this week and try to get better,‚Äù Rhule said.

On the injury front, Rhule confirmed defensive backs Malcolm Hartzog and Javin Wright will return after missing last week‚Äôs game as a precaution.

Rhule, who attended Terence ‚ÄúBud‚Äù Crawford‚Äôs recent fight in Las Vegas, said he wants his team to seize its own opportunity on the national stage against a ranked opponent.

Kickoff between Nebraska and Michigan is set for Saturday in Lincoln at 2:30 PM CST.

snippet.title: Ricketts and Osborn trade barbs in NE Senate race
snippet.description:
KEARNEY, Neb. ‚Äî Senator Pete Ricketts made a stop in Kearney as part of his statewide reelection campaign, where he took aim at his opponent, Dan Osborn. Ricketts accused Osborn of being a Democrat who would obstruct former President Trump's agenda.

"You can bet that's where he's going to put his allegiance if he were to get elected. That's why it's so important that we beat fake Dan Osborn and send a real conservative to Washington," said Ricketts.

Osborn, who previously ran against Deb Fischer in 2024 and made national headlines when he garnered 46.7% of the vote, is also conducting a series of town halls. He previously emphasized his opposition to the "One Big Beautiful Bill" and his connection to the working class, contrasting his background with Ricketts'.

"Ricketts is certainly a bigger contrast from me. This story writes itself about his background and my background," said Osborn.

Ricketts' event featured remarks from Representative Adrian Smith and local officials, including Kearney Mayor Jonathan Nikkila, State Senator Stan Clouse and State Board of Education Representative Sherry Jones. In contrast, Osborn's previous town hall in Hastings was more informal and included a question-and-answer session.

Read more: https://nebraska.tv/news/local/ricketts-and-osborn-trade-barbs-in-nebraska-senate-race#

snippet.title: Malcom Hartzog‚Äôs Late Interception Seals Nebraska Win Over Cincinnati in Arrowhead Opener
snippet.description:
Nebraska defensive back Malcolm Hartzog Jr. intercepted a pass in the end zone with 34 seconds remaining, sealing a season-opening victory for the Huskers at Arrowhead Stadium on Saturday night.

The play capped a night where first-year defensive coordinator John Butler‚Äôs emphasis on situational football paid off. ‚ÄúYeah, this is going to build us some confidence for sure,‚Äù Hartzog said. ‚ÄúA lot of people say we can‚Äôt win a close game, so winning that close game right there just makes us know we can do it.‚Äù

While the defense made the final stop, the Huskers will look to shore up their rushing defense before next week‚Äôs matchup against Akron. Nebraska allowed 202 rushing yards on 30 carries.

On the offensive side, new starting running back Emmett Johnson delivered in his debut. Johnson carried the ball 25 times for more than 108 yards and added 10 receptions for 27 yards. ‚ÄúFeels great, man, but I can only give credit to my O-line,‚Äù Johnson said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm willing to do whatever it takes for this team to win.‚Äù

 Sophomore Quarterback Dylan Raiola, entering his second season as the starter, threw for 243 yards and two touchdowns, including a fourth-and-2 conversion to transfer wide receiver Dane Key. Raiola said the win was encouraging but noted room for improvement. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs some third downs, some fourth downs that we wish we could have had back, but that‚Äôs game one and the growing pains,‚Äù Raiola said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just glad we left here with a W.‚Äù

Raiola had ice on his hand postgame but did not comment on any injury. Head coach Matt Rhule also did not mention it.

Nebraska fans dominated the Arrowhead crowd of more than 70,000. Rhule estimated 65,000 supporters made the trip south to Kansas City, creating an atmosphere reminiscent of Memorial Stadium.

The Huskers (1-0) return to Lincoln next Saturday for their home opener at Memorial Stadium against Akron. Kickoff is set for 6:30 p.m.

snippet.title: Nebraska Volleyball: Dani Busboom Kelly Breaks Down Passing, Offense, and Illinois/Minnesota Prep
snippet.description:
Nebraska head coach Dani Busboom Kelly meets with the media to discuss the Huskers‚Äô upcoming matches and where the team is trending. She says she isn‚Äôt concerned about passing, noting the team is putting up strong numbers and that the criticism is mostly nitpicking. She highlights Bergen‚Äôs strong play, the historic offensive numbers the team is producing, and the mindset of taking things point by point instead of overanalyzing individual moments.

Dani talks about the consistency of hitting .300 as a team and how impressive it is to do it night after night with a balanced offense. She credits Bergen for blocking well, sticking to game plans, and making adjustments even when those plans change from match to match. She also expands on her coaching philosophy and how the team continues to grow with clean play and high-level execution.

Looking ahead, Dani says Illinois is off to a great start and points out their setter, who she played against in her Louisville days when the setter was at Florida State. She says Illinois‚Äô outside is playing at a high level and that it‚Äôs always fun to coach against former assistants. She also previews Minnesota, a team dealing with injuries but still staying in the top 25 with one of the best outsides in the country. She expects a challenge on the road.

Dani closes by talking about what it means for high school teams to get to play at the Devaney Center and how big of a deal that experience is.

snippet.title: Huskers Volleyball Prep for Alumni Match
snippet.description:
The Nebraska volleyball team is gearing up for its annual alumni match Saturday at the Bob Devaney Sports Center, now home to the newly named John Cook Arena.

Head coach Dani Busboom Kelly said she‚Äôs eager for her team to face new opponents while also seeing familiar faces from the program‚Äôs past.

‚ÄúYou‚Äôd like to think we‚Äôre going to be quite a bit more organized, so we have an edge, but you can‚Äôt count out Olympians,‚Äù Busboom Kelly said. ‚ÄúSome of these players haven‚Äôt played in the last month, but they just finished pro seasons, and we‚Äôre playing at a really high level. I‚Äôm expecting them to be pretty good on the other side.‚Äù

Among the alumni returning are stars such as Jordan Larson, Lauren Stiverins, Kenzie Maloney, Allie Badenhorst, and Lindsey Krause. For Busboom Kelly, the focus is on sharpening fundamentals and testing the depth of her roster.

‚ÄúOur practices are really tough,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs just going to make us stronger in the end. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm very excited to play against somebody else.‚Äù

With the alumni match only six days before Nebraska‚Äôs first game in the AVCA Kickoff, the contest serves as a true test of where the team stands.

Outside hitter Harper Murray said fall practice has been intense. ‚ÄúTwo-a-days are really hard, but we get through it together,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm looking forward to facing some familiar faces and meeting some of the alumni. It‚Äôs gonna be fun playing against them.‚Äù

Assistant coach and alum Kelly Hunter Natter will also step onto the court for the match. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really exciting,‚Äù Natter said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a good chance to see a lot of my former teammates and alums that you don‚Äôt get to see all that often.‚Äù

Busboom Kelly said if the alumni match proves successful, the program hopes to make it an annual tradition, similar to other top volleyball programs.

The match takes place Saturday, August 16th at 6 PM at the Bob Devaney Sports Center.

snippet.title: Nebraska Volleyball Ready to Make History Playing at PBA
snippet.description:
Nebraska volleyball is preparing to make its debut at Pinnacle Bank Arena, a stage the program has never played on before. While the Huskers have hosted games at Memorial Stadium and the Devaney Sports Center, Friday‚Äôs matchup against Pitt will mark the first time the team takes the court in the 16,000-seat arena.

‚Äú24 hours from now, 16,000 fans will pack it out, seeing Big Red and PBA for the first time,‚Äù Nebraska head coach Dani Busboom-Kelly said. ‚ÄúI feel like we‚Äôve done everything as a program, and this is one thing I get to do as a head coach, so that‚Äôs pretty cool.‚Äù

Team captains say the experience feels monumental.

‚ÄúIt feels like we‚Äôre in December already, like a Final Four environment,‚Äù junior setter Bergren Reilly said. ‚ÄúWe know the fans are going to bring it, which will make it even better.‚Äù

Being named captain is an honor, the players said, but not the team‚Äôs ultimate goal.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a big honor to be a captain at Nebraska, but everybody knows that‚Äôs not the main goal of the season,‚Äù said Reilly. 

Senior middle blocker Rebekah Allick said, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs something I‚Äôll get to look back on, but right now it doesn‚Äôt change much. We already have so many leaders.‚Äù

The team has practiced at the Devaney Sports Center and says the transition to PBA will be smooth.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôll be really cool to have a big home-court advantage,‚Äù Reilly said. ‚ÄúWe get to be in a bigger place than Devaney, and we‚Äôve watched a lot of other events here. It‚Äôs exciting to be one of them.‚Äù

The Huskers will face Pitt at 6 PM CST on Friday in the first match at Pinnacle Bank Arena.

snippet.title: Huskers Football Big Win vs. Cinci | Huskers Volleyball Reverse Sweep vs. KY | NTV Sports Pod 16
snippet.description:
It was a huge weekend for the Huskers, and we break it all down on this episode.

Nebraska football opened the season with a 20‚Äì17 win over Cincinnati at Arrowhead Stadium. Sophomore quarterback Dylan Raiola threw for 243 yards and two touchdowns, running back Emmett Johnson added 108 yards on the ground, and Malcolm Hartzog Jr. sealed the game with an interception in the end zone with 34 seconds left. The victory marked Nebraska‚Äôs first season-opening win over a Power Five opponent since 2003.

On the volleyball court, No. 1 Nebraska stormed back to reverse sweep No. 7 Kentucky in Nashville. After dropping the first two sets, the Huskers responded with a 25‚Äì19, 25‚Äì23, 15‚Äì8 finish to claim the match. Harper Murray led the way with a career-high 23 kills, hitting .340 with 15 digs and 5 blocks. Key lineup changes by head coach Dani Busboom Kelly after set 2 included Olivia Mauch stepping in at libero and Virginia Adriano at opposite, which helped spark the comeback. Nebraska outhit Kentucky .221 to .168 and won the dig battle 73‚Äì60.

Both teams showed grit and resilience, setting the tone for the season ahead.

snippet.title: Kearney restaurant owners respond to backlash over Kirk post.
snippet.description:
KEARNEY, Neb. ‚Äî A local Kearney business owner has spoken out to clarify remarks she made on social media following the shooting of Charlie Kirk, a few weeks ago. Which sparked significant backlash and misunderstanding.

Cindy Houlden, silent partner at The Lodge Restaurant, addressed the controversy surrounding a Facebook post that was quickly shared and taken out of context. She explained that her original post was online for less than a minute and that only part of it was circulated widely.

‚ÄúOur grandmother used to say there‚Äôs three sides to every story: his side, her side, and the truth. Well, there‚Äôs three sides to this story, too," said Houlden.

To clarify what was actually said online, Houlden emphasized that she did not justify the shooting in any way. Instead, her message focused on the broader consequences of division and hatred in the country. ‚ÄúWhat I meant by karma is the karma we all have to live with with our actions as we go forward,‚Äù she said. She expressed concern that ongoing societal divisions could lead to further tragedies.

‚ÄúMy post said that what happened to Charlie Kirk is not justified in any way shape or form," added Houlden. "No matter how divisive some people may have found his words, but with that said what I meant by karma is the karma we all have to live with, with our actions as we go forward.‚Äù

Despite her intentions to promote reflection and unity, Houlden and the business faced immediate backlash. Threatening comments flooded her social media, prompting Facebook to warn her about potential threats. Sales at The Lodge have reportedly dropped significantly.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve seen a major impact on the sales and what‚Äôs happened to the business,‚Äù noted Robert James, The Lodge Restaurant Co-Owner and Kitchen Manager.

This crushes James. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs breaking my heart to see it die,‚Äù he said.

Hatred didn‚Äôt stop with simply attacking the owners and their business. Houlden mentioned threats were made against her employees including coming after high schoolers. ‚ÄúWhen this initially happened, we lost 80% of our workforce,‚Äù said James.

The threats extended beyond the owners to employees, including young workers and local students. In response, Houlden contacted Kearney Public Schools and the University of Nebraska at Kearney to alert them to threats circulating online.

Houlden called for open dialogue and community unity, urging people to come together over shared meals and conversations. ‚ÄúWhen you have children, is this the world you want them to grow up in?‚Äù she asked.

She said she hopes to stop what she called destructive behavior. ‚ÄúAnd I feel it towards both sides, but I‚Äôve never felt the hate from the left that I feel from the right. I‚Äôll be honest,‚Äù noted Houlden.

She also clarified her role in the business, stating that James primarily owns and operates The Lodge while she manages the books and finances. Both owners have expressed disbelief at how the situation escalated.

The incident highlights growing tensions in communities across the country, underscoring the challenges faced by individuals trying to express nuanced views in a highly polarized environment.

snippet.title: Nebraska Football Head Coach Matt Rhule Signs Contract Extension
snippet.description:
Stability is the theme in Lincoln as Nebraska head coach Matt Rhule has signed a contract extension that keeps him with the Cornhuskers through 2032.

Rhule, who originally signed a deal through 2030, said earlier this year that he wanted to stay in Lincoln ‚Äî and made good on that statement by putting pen to paper.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm very, very grateful to Troy Dannen, to UNL President Gold, to the board for their confidence in me and our staff,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúVery grateful to my wife and kids who allowed me to do this job and moved here. I‚Äôm very grateful to the fan base, the city of Lincoln, and the state of Nebraska. This has become our home.‚Äù

Rhule added that the new deal is about stability and long-term success, not just for himself but for the program.

‚ÄúHopefully it sends a message to recruits and players that this is the place to be ‚Äî and we want to be here,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúI love this team and I love where we‚Äôre headed.‚Äù

Nebraska Athletic Director Troy Dannen said conversations about the extension began over the summer and intensified around Week 3 of the season.

‚ÄúI believe in the program. I believe in Matt,‚Äù Dannen said. ‚ÄúWe needed to get the buyout reset if we possibly could. That‚Äôs really why I initiated the discussions when I did.‚Äù

The new contract does not include a base salary increase but does reset the buyout and add performance-based incentives. Rhule will continue to earn $7.5 million this year, increasing to $12.5 million by 2030. Each time Nebraska reaches the College Football Playoff Round of 16, his base pay rises by another $1 million.

Since arriving in Lincoln, Rhule has guided the Huskers to their first winning season in eight years and their first bowl victory since 2015. This fall, Nebraska is 6‚Äì2, marking the program‚Äôs best eight-game start in nine seasons.

‚ÄúWe could have gone somewhere else probably ‚Äî but we want to be here,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúNot like, ‚ÄòHey, we‚Äôve got to be here.‚Äô We want to be here.‚Äù

For Nebraska fans and recruits alike, the message is clear: Rhule, Dannen, and the administration are united ‚Äî and they believe the best years for Cornhusker football are still ahead.

Reactions and Thoughts from NTV's Sports Team After Nebraska Loses to Michigan
snippet.description:
In a tightly contested Big Ten opener, No. 21 Michigan edged Nebraska 30‚Äì27 on Saturday at Memorial Stadium in Lincoln. The Wolverines improved to 3‚Äì1 overall and 1‚Äì0 in conference play, while the Cornhuskers fell to 3‚Äì1 and 0‚Äì1 in the Big Ten. 

Michigan's offense was propelled by a dominant ground game, amassing 286 rushing yards. Running back Justice Haynes led the charge with 149 yards on 17 carries, including a 75-yard touchdown run. Freshman quarterback Bryce Underwood added 105 passing yards and a 37-yard touchdown run. Jordan Marshall contributed with a 54-yard touchdown run, marking his first significant play of the season. 
Maize n Brew

Defensively, the Wolverines were relentless, recording seven sacks and 10 tackles for loss. Linebacker Cole Sullivan had a standout performance with an interception, a sack, and six tackles. True freshman safety Jayden Sanders stepped up in the absence of Zeke Berry, recording eight tackles and solid coverage on crucial third downs. 
Maize n Brew

Nebraska's quarterback Dylan Raiola threw for 308 yards and three touchdowns, connecting with Jacory Barney Jr. for two scores. Running back Emmett Johnson added 67 rushing yards, but the Huskers' offense struggled to establish a consistent ground game, totaling just 43 rushing yards. 
Wikipedia

The game featured dramatic momentum swings. After trailing 10‚Äì0, Nebraska rallied to tie the game at 17‚Äì17 by halftime, highlighted by a 52-yard Hail Mary touchdown pass from Raiola to Barney Jr. However, Michigan's second-half scoring, including a 56-yard field goal and a 54-yard touchdown run, proved decisive. 

Michigan's victory extended its winning streak against Nebraska to five games and improved its all-time series lead to 9‚Äì4‚Äì1. The Wolverines also secured their sixth consecutive win in a Big Ten opener. 
University of Michigan Athletics

Nebraska will look to rebound in its next conference matchup, aiming to build on the resilience shown in a hard-fought game against a ranked opponent.

snippet.title: Dani Busboom Kelly's Era at Nebraska Starts with Big Wins with Laney Choboy Shining at Libero
snippet.description:
LINCOLN, Neb. ‚Äî The Dani Busboom Kelly era of Nebraska volleyball is off to a dominant start. The Huskers opened the season with back-to-back wins over top-six opponents (3. Pittsburgh and 6. Stanford), and another top-10 challenge looms with No. 7 Kentucky next.

The early success has come with an emphasis on defense and chemistry. Players say the support within the team has been just as important as the competition.

‚ÄúYes, we push each other every day ‚Äî every practice is a battle,‚Äù freshman outsider hitter Teraya Sigler said. ‚ÄúBut we are also so happy for each other and willing to support each other in whatever that looks like. Everyone is all in with wanting to be the best teammates they can.‚Äù

That buy-in has been especially evident at libero, a position that has produced some of Nebraska‚Äôs most iconic names, including Busboom Kelly herself. This fall, sophomore Laney Choboy has stepped into the role vacated by All-American Lexi Rodriguez.

Choboy said her growth has been as much mental as physical. ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt really my skill that improved, it was my mentality,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWhat I was going to let affect me, what I was going to let into my body and my heart. The mental side made the biggest difference.‚Äù

She acknowledged the challenge of following Rodriguez, but said she has embraced it. ‚ÄúI learned from Lexi and will continue to use her as a resource, but I‚Äôm also my own player,‚Äù Choboy said. ‚ÄúI can do this. While I‚Äôm stepping into the role she left behind, I‚Äôm coming into it on my own.‚Äù

Carrying the libero torch is not lost on Choboy, who called it a dream come true. ‚ÄúNebraska has a legacy of big-time liberos,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúJustine and Lexi going on to the Olympics ‚Äî it‚Äôs insane to think I‚Äôm in this position now. I‚Äôm just grateful to be here and hope to carry on that legacy.‚Äù

Busboom Kelly said her team is embracing the challenges ahead, including Kentucky.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm excited to play Kentucky,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThis weekend was a challenge, and Kentucky has the talent to be a team in December that makes it all the way, in my opinion. It‚Äôll be a heck of a challenge for us.‚Äù

With Busboom Kelly at the helm, Nebraska‚Äôs start to 2025 already looks like the foundation for another historic run.

snippet.title: Nebraska Football Ready for Road Test at Maryland
snippet.description:
Nebraska football coach Matt Rhule says his team is ready for a big-time matchup against the 4-1 Maryland Terrapins this weekend. The Huskers, also 4-1, will travel to face Maryland.

‚ÄúThey respect the heck out of the team that we‚Äôre facing,‚Äù Rhule said during his weekly press conference on Thursday. ‚ÄúThey know the battle that it‚Äôs going to be. That‚Äôs the message, and our guys have gotten that loud and clear.‚Äù

Rule confirmed that defensive back Malcolm Hartzog Jr. is doubtful and likely will not travel with the team. With a Northeaster expected to impact the East Coast, Nebraska practiced with wet footballs all week to prepare for potential rainy conditions.

Nebraska‚Äôs defense has been a key strength this season. Against Michigan State last week, the Huskers recorded five sacks and 14 quarterback hurries, consistently pressuring the pocket. Maryland‚Äôs true freshman quarterback, Malik Washington, has passed for 1,257 yards with nine touchdowns and two interceptions. Rhule described Washington as a dual-threat player, but Nebraska boasts the nation‚Äôs top-ranked pass defense, allowing just 90 yards per game.

‚ÄúWith the possibility of rain, the passing game may not see much action,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúThat means our front seven have to step up and create the energy."

The Huskers‚Äô offense also faces pressure. Quarterback Dylan Raiola has been sacked 12 times over the past two games ‚Äî seven against Michigan and five against Michigan State. 

Rhule emphasized that not all of the responsibility lies with the offensive line, but they know improvement is needed. Protecting Raiola will be crucial for Nebraska‚Äôs offense, which ranks eighth nationally at 320 yards per game.

Kick off is Saturday at 2:30 p.m. Central.

snippet.title: Nebraska Volleyball Sweeps Northwestern to Stay Undefeated
snippet.description:
Press Release Courtesy of Nebraska Athletics-

The No. 1 Nebraska volleyball team posted its 10th sweep in a row with a 25-17, 25-13, 25-17 victory over Northwestern in front of 8,516 fans at John Cook Arena at the Bob Devaney Sports Center on Friday night.

In their annual Pink Match, the Huskers (19-0, 9-0 B1G) hit .357 and held Northwestern (13-8, 3-6 B1G) to .099.

Nebraska improved its streak of consecutive sets won to 31, which tied the 2009 team for the longest streak since 2007 (53 sets in a row).

Harper Murray had nine kills and eight digs, while Rebekah Allick and Teraya Sigler each had seven kills and hit .417. Andi Jackson pounded six kills and added five blocks, and Virginia Adriano and Manaia Ogbechie added five and four kills, respectively.

Bergen Reilly notched 30 assists and moved within 10 assists of Lauren Cook (3,198) for fourth in school history in career assists in the rally-scoring era.

Laney Choboy had a match-high 10 digs.

snippet.title: Nebraska cannabis board faces delays after resignations and legal charges
snippet.description:
The Nebraska Medical Cannabis Commission Board convened Tuesday despite the recent resignations of members Bruce Bailey and Kim Lowe, who stepped down at the request of Gov. Jim Pillen. The resignations followed the indictment of Hobert Rupe, executive director of the Liquor Control Commission, on seven charges. Prosecutors allege Rupe provided favors to a Lincoln strip club owner in exchange for cash, dances, and sexual favors. The reasons behind Bailey and Lowe's resignations remain unclear, but Gov. Pillen expressed gratitude for their service, stating, "I appreciate the willingness of Bruce and Kim to serve, and I thank them for the time they have been on the commission."

By law, members of the Liquor Control Commission also serve on the Medical Cannabis Commission. Gov. Pillen is currently accepting applications to fill the vacancies and will appoint two new members. The board faced an October 1 deadline to approve the state's four cannabis cultivators and release permanent regulations. Monica Oldenburg confirmed that one task has been completed: "The emergency regulations approved at the September 8 meeting have been approved and signed by the governor and are in full force and in effect until 11:59 p.m. on December 7, at which time they will expire unless extended for a second 90-day period."

Despite receiving 39 cultivator applications, the board could not select the four cultivators. An evaluation team, which included Bailey and Lowe, was tasked with reviewing the applications. The commission intended for the team to provide licensure recommendations at Tuesday's meeting. Lorelle Mueting emphasized the board's commitment to resolving the issue, saying, "We just ask, I guess, for your understanding that this is a situation that none of us created and this is where we‚Äôre at right here. We hope you understand that we‚Äôre working through this the best we can to get the licenses issued in a timely manner."

Read more: https://nebraska.tv/news/local/nebraska-cannabis-board-faces-delays-after-resignations-and-legal-charges#

snippet.title: Gabe Kowalek as new chief of police in Kearney
snippet.description:
Kowalek emphasized the importance of connecting with the community throughout his career. "Sometimes we deal with some tough situations, and we really need to be the light in the dark situation, and just be positive. Treat people with respect. Be professional, always... being thorough in all your investigations," he said.

He expressed his intention to continue strengthen relationships with the Buffalo County Sheriff's Office, Nebraska State Patrol, and agencies like the FBI. Kowalek says that his leadership style differs in some ways from the previous chiefs but says he is committed to training and developing officers into leaders. 

"You know, as long as they're being professional, respectful, could justify what they did to keep the community safe, to build that community trust, we're going to develop leaders," he said.

snippet.title: Huskers Show Grit in 28‚Äì21 Win over Northwestern, Bounce Back from Minnesota Loss
snippet.description:
Nebraska head coach Matt Rhule pushed back on the idea that the Huskers lost focus in preparation for last week‚Äôs loss at Minnesota, saying his team ‚Äúdid not take our feet off the gas pedal‚Äù as they now turn their attention to Northwestern.

The response came after tight end Luke Lindemeier said Tuesday that Nebraska lost focus in the week leading up to the 24‚Äì6 setback in Minneapolis. Rhule disagreed, emphasizing that both last week and this week have featured strong practices.

‚ÄúI thought we had a great week of work,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúOur guys haven‚Äôt taken their foot off the gas.‚Äù

Nebraska will need that urgency against a Northwestern offense built on a physical ground game. The Wildcats are averaging 190 rushing yards per game, sixth best in the Big Ten. Rhule praised Northwestern‚Äôs offensive front and explosive running backs.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre unbelievably well-coached up front,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúTheir backs have great bursts and they‚Äôre as athletic as we‚Äôll see. They have home-run ability.‚Äù

The matchup puts pressure on a Nebraska defense ranked 15th in the Big Ten in rushing defense, allowing 157 yards per game. However, if the Huskers can keep the Wildcats behind the sticks, the advantage flips. Nebraska owns the nation‚Äôs top-ranked pass defense, while Northwestern enters with the No. 112 passing offense.

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt let 1st-and-10 become 2nd-and-5,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going to come down to our ability to get off blocks and make tackles.‚Äù

Nebraska received mixed injury news entering the weekend. Starting right guard Rocco Spindler, who left the Minnesota game with a finger injury, is expected to play. Rhule called the decision a matter of pain tolerance and said Spindler practiced all week. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a baller,‚Äù Rhule said.

On the other side of the ledger, defensive back Malcolm Hartzog will miss the remainder of the season. He will redshirt after undergoing surgery for a core-muscle injury.

Nebraska (5‚Äì2, 2‚Äì2 Big Ten) and Northwestern (5‚Äì2, 3‚Äì1) kick off at 11 a.m. Saturday at Memorial Stadium.

snippet.title: Matt Rhule Press Conference for Houston Christian | Nebraska Football Presser
snippet.description:
LINCOLN ‚Äî Nebraska head coach Matt Rhule opened his end-of-week press conference with reflection and perspective as the Huskers turn their attention to Houston Christian.

Rhule said the team visited the 9/11 Memorial before their bowl game in New York last season, an experience he believes gave players valuable perspective. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs important to remind them what it means, to encourage our guys to tell people you love them,‚Äù Rhule said. He also congratulated Nebraska‚Äôs newest Hall of Fame inductees, highlighting Brett Maher‚Äôs rare achievement of earning All-Big Ten honors as both a punter and kicker.

Rhule shared his own memories of Sept. 11, 2001, when he was a coach at UCLA. ‚ÄúI remember the helpless feeling of being in Los Angeles, watching it in the facilities,‚Äù he said. With a family member who died in a plane crash, Rhule said the tragedy hit close to home. He emphasized the importance of bringing those stories to life for players who weren‚Äôt yet born.

Looking ahead, Rhule stressed this week is about improvement. ‚ÄúIf we don‚Äôt play better than we played last week, then we didn‚Äôt play better,‚Äù he said. The coach added that he was pleased with practice and with a recent video the program released, saying it set the standard he expects.

Rhule also weighed in on the NCAA transfer portal, questioning why it doesn‚Äôt align with the financial year. ‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt we just do what the NFL does? They‚Äôre doing so well,‚Äù he said.

Quarterback Dylan Raiola continues to be a focal point, with Saturday marking his 16th career game. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs still so young in his journey, but he‚Äôs doing it at such an advanced level,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs at level four now with his understanding. We‚Äôve elevated what we do with him, and he‚Äôs taken it to a whole other level.‚Äù

Houston Christian‚Äôs defense presents challenges, Rhule added, noting they‚Äôve allowed only one third-down conversion this season while constantly showing different looks. ‚ÄúWe have to do a better job getting to the quarterback,‚Äù he said.

Rhule also praised left tackle Gunnar Gottula, calling him ‚Äúan excellent player with long arms and toughness‚Äù who has returned even stronger from surgery. Meanwhile, cornerback Malcolm Hartzog is questionable this week, meaning Jamir Conn could see more playing time.

Nebraska (2-0) will host Houston Christian (1-1) at Memorial Stadium on Saturday. Kickoff is set for 11 a.m. CT.

snippet.title: Matt Rhule Shares Thoughts on Cincinnati Win, Previews Akron, WR Bonner Out with Torn ACL
snippet.description:
Nebraska head coach Matt Rhule reflected on his team‚Äôs 20-17 win over Cincinnati and looked ahead to Saturday‚Äôs home opener against Akron during his weekly press conference on Monday.

Rhule said he is eager to return to Memorial Stadium for a night game.

‚ÄúObviously, we‚Äôre excited to come back home, play at home this week versus Akron,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúJoe Moorhead is a coach I have a long history with and a lot of respect for.‚Äù

The Huskers will be without tight end Janiran Bonner, who suffered a season-ending torn ACL. Rhule described Bonner as a ‚Äúselfless teammate‚Äù who has meant a great deal to the program.

Defensively, Nebraska gave up more than 200 rushing yards against the Bearcats, with 96 of those yards coming from quarterback runs. Rhule admitted the Huskers struggled with containment.

‚ÄúAnytime you give up 200 yards rushing, you‚Äôre not gonna be real happy,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know if we did a good enough job as coaches of getting our players ready.‚Äù

Still, Rhule credited his secondary for limiting Cincinnati to just 69 yards through the air.

On offense, running back Emmett Johnson carried the load, something Rhule said he wasn‚Äôt completely comfortable with.

‚ÄúI wasn‚Äôt happy with it,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúI wanted to get Izaac and Mekhi in, but Emmett was hot. We went with Emmett.‚Äù

Rhule praised quarterback Dylan Raiola, who threw 42 passes without a turnover.

‚ÄúHe has more freedom than most quarterbacks in the country, and he‚Äôs right most of the time,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúSo I thought he played excellent.‚Äù

Rhule also confirmed Raiola is healthy after appearing with ice on his hand after the Cincinnati game. ‚ÄúHe took a hit in the game. He threw on Sunday. You‚Äôll see him playing against Akron,‚Äù Rhule said.

Nebraska didn‚Äôt return from Kansas City until 4 a.m. Friday, altering the team‚Äôs weekly schedule. The Huskers skipped weight training that day, instead reviewing film in the afternoon. Players rested on Saturday before returning to film review and practice on Sunday.

Nebraska faces Akron on Saturday night at Memorial Stadium.

snippet.title: Huskers Women‚Äôs Soccer Plays to 1-1 Draw Against Missouri State
snippet.description:
On a hot and windy afternoon at Barbara Hibner Field, the Nebraska women‚Äôs soccer team settled for a 1-1 draw against Missouri State in its second home match of the season.

The Huskers (1-0-1) dominated possession early, recording 20 shots in the game, but could not break through in the first half. Their best moment before the break came when goalkeeper CeCe Villa saved a Missouri State penalty, diving to her right to keep the score level.

The Bears (0-1-1) struck first in the second half, when Rowann Law scored with a left-footed strike less than 10 minutes after the restart.

Nebraska responded quickly. Ella Rudney equalized with a long-range shot that flew into the top corner, bringing the home crowd to its feet.

Both teams had chances to find a winner in the closing minutes, but Missouri State goalkeeper Ella Becker stood strong, making multiple saves to deny the Huskers.

Head coach John Walker said his team struggled with execution in the heat and wind.

‚ÄúWe gave up a goal and at least came back into the game and had some very good chances down the stretch,‚Äù Walker said. ‚ÄúAt the end of the day, from a result standpoint, this is a game that we need to win.‚Äù

Nebraska travels to Oklahoma State on Aug. 21 before returning home to face Weber State on Aug. 28.

snippet.title: Political newcomer Nate Ostdiek launches campaign for NE Legislature seat
snippet.description:
With Senator Machaela Cavanaugh term-limited in 2026, political newcomer Nate Ostdiek has announced his campaign to represent central Omaha. The 22-year-old registered Democrat recently testified against the McCook Immigration Detention Facility at a hearing, criticizing the governor's approach.

"I think it's wrong and I think the governor is using it as a way to distract from his failing leadership and the rest of the Republican Party's failing leadership in the state," said Ostdiek. "They‚Äôve decided to bully immigrants and really demonize a lot of people instead of actually addressing the problems that Nebraskans are facing."

Ostdiek emphasized the importance of transparency in his campaign. "I've always been active in legislature for the last several years since I became civically engaged. I've talked to numerous other bills and shown up to testify," he said.

snippet.title: Matt Rhule Shares Thughts on 9/11 and Previews Match up vs. HCU
snippet.description:
LINCOLN ‚Äî Nebraska head coach Matt Rhule opened his end-of-week press conference with reflection and perspective as the Huskers turn their attention to Houston Christian.

Rhule said the team visited the 9/11 Memorial before their bowl game in New York last season, an experience he believes gave players valuable perspective. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs important to remind them what it means, to encourage our guys to tell people you love them,‚Äù Rhule said. He also congratulated Nebraska‚Äôs newest Hall of Fame inductees, highlighting Brett Maher‚Äôs rare achievement of earning All-Big Ten honors as both a punter and kicker.

Rhule shared his own memories of Sept. 11, 2001, when he was a coach at UCLA. ‚ÄúI remember the helpless feeling of being in Los Angeles, watching it in the facilities,‚Äù he said. With a family member who died in a plane crash, Rhule said the tragedy hit close to home. He emphasized the importance of bringing those stories to life for players who weren‚Äôt yet born.

Looking ahead, Rhule stressed this week is about improvement. ‚ÄúIf we don‚Äôt play better than we played last week, then we didn‚Äôt play better,‚Äù he said. The coach added that he was pleased with practice and with a recent video the program released, saying it set the standard he expects.

Rhule also weighed in on the NCAA transfer portal, questioning why it doesn‚Äôt align with the financial year. ‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt we just do what the NFL does? They‚Äôre doing so well,‚Äù he said.

Quarterback Dylan Raiola continues to be a focal point, with Saturday marking his 16th career game. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs still so young in his journey, but he‚Äôs doing it at such an advanced level,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs at level four now with his understanding. We‚Äôve elevated what we do with him, and he‚Äôs taken it to a whole other level.‚Äù

Houston Christian‚Äôs defense presents challenges, Rhule added, noting they‚Äôve allowed only one third-down conversion this season while constantly showing different looks. ‚ÄúWe have to do a better job getting to the quarterback,‚Äù he said.

Rhule also praised left tackle Gunnar Gottula, calling him ‚Äúan excellent player with long arms and toughness‚Äù who has returned even stronger from surgery. Meanwhile, cornerback Malcolm Hartzog is questionable this week, meaning Jamir Conn could see more playing time.

Nebraska (2-0) will host Houston Christian (1-1) at Memorial Stadium on Saturday. Kickoff is set for 11 a.m. CT.

snippet.title: Nebraska Volleyball's Teraya Sigler Makes Immediate Impact for as True Freshman
snippet.description:
LINCOLN, Neb. ‚Äî Nebraska volleyball is no stranger to reloading, whether through transfers or freshmen ready to contribute from day one. This fall, one of the brightest early storylines belongs to true freshman Teraya Sigler.

Sigler, the nation‚Äôs No. 1 overall recruit out of Horizon High School in Arizona, started Nebraska‚Äôs opening weekend matches against No. 3 Pittsburgh and No. 6 Stanford. A two-time Gatorade Arizona Player of the Year and a gold medalist with the U.S. U21 and U19 national teams, she entered Lincoln with a decorated resume and quickly found herself on the court under the sport‚Äôs brightest lights.

‚ÄúThe first five points I was kind of like, ‚ÄòWhere am I? What am I doing?‚Äô‚Äù Sigler said. ‚ÄúThen my teammates reminded me we‚Äôre just playing volleyball. It‚Äôs just a big game in a big arena with a lot of people.‚Äù

Sigler, typically an outside hitter, has been adjusting to a new role to fit Nebraska‚Äôs lineup needs. She notched one kill against both Pittsburgh and Stanford, and added a service ace against the Cardinal. While her stat line was modest, her energy and composure drew praise from coaches and teammates alike.

‚ÄúI love to help this team however they need me,‚Äù Sigler said. ‚ÄúI see it as an opportunity to prove myself and be the best I possibly can in that position.‚Äù

Nebraska has leaned on freshmen before ‚Äî setter Bergen Reilly started last year en route to All-America honors, while Harper Murray and Andi Jackson each made early impacts. Sigler now joins that list, showing confidence that belies her age.

For coach Dani Busboom Kelly, Sigler‚Äôs presence on the court has already made a difference. ‚ÄúHer energy was so much fun,‚Äù Busboom Kelly said. ‚ÄúWhether she‚Äôs in the game or coming off for a rotation, she brings the same perspective and vibes.‚Äù

With her debut behind her, Sigler appears poised to grow into her role as the season continues. In front of more than 16,000 fans at Pinnacle Bank Arena, she showed the nerves didn‚Äôt last long.

She‚Äôs used to the spotlight, and Nebraska believes she‚Äôs ready to shine in it again.

snippet.title: LPD investigate murder-suicide amid domestic violence concerns.
snippet.description:
The Lincoln Police Department is investigating a murder-suicide after discovering a couple deceased inside a home. 51-year-old Jennifer McCarther, a mother of three and grandmother to five, was found with multiple gunshot wounds, while 51-year-old Sterling Jordan had a single gunshot wound to the head. Autopsies are pending to confirm the time, manner, and cause of death.

LPD Chief Michon Morrow stated that officers responded to a welfare check around 10:45 a.m. Friday, where they found McCarther and Jordan deceased. Jordan's employer had called for a welfare check the previous day when he did not report to work. Officers initially did not force entry due to the routine nature of welfare checks. However, a second call prompted further investigation, leading to the discovery.

This marks the third serious domestic violence case in Lincoln in 2025. Leah Dorge from Friendship Home noted an increase in the number of people seeking shelter and housing services, with an average of 167 people daily, a number that has tripled over the last decade. Natalie Robert-Day emphasized that domestic violence often begins with controlling behavior rather than physical violence.

McCarther's family is grieving, hoping to prevent similar tragedies. "Losing her has left a hole in our hearts that will never be filled, but her love and light continue to live on through all of us who are blessed to know her," the family said in a statement.

snippet.title: Elwood residents seek solutions after grocery store closure
snippet.description:
The Elwood Hometown Cooperative Market closed it's doors for the final time in March of this year, to the dismay of many residents. Now, the Center for Rural Affairs is investigating the factors behind the shutdown and exploring ways to ensure the availability of grocery stores in rural areas.

"It's incredibly difficult to own and operate a grocery store in a rural place, and it can also be difficult for rural grocery stores to have the purchasing power of larger competitors, such as a Dollar General or a Walmart," said Audra Espinoza, state policy manager for the Center for Rural Affairs.

Residents of Elwood, along with local grocers, a legislative aide, and other concerned parties gathered to share their experiences and discuss adaptations following the store's closure. Many now face a nearly half-hour drive to Lexington or rely on deliveries from Walmart.

To read more visit: https://nebraska.tv/news/local/elwood-residents-seek-solutions-after-grocery-store-closure#

snippet.title: Cattle prices surge to record highs at NE sale barns
snippet.description:
Two livestock markets in central Nebraska saw record-breaking feeder cattle prices last week. This a sign of long-awaited relief for ranchers and sale barn operators who‚Äôve endured years of tight margins.

Rick Shoemaker, owner of Huss and Lexington Livestock Markets, said business is thriving as demand outpaces supply and more buyers show up ready to bid.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a great time to be running a sale barn,‚Äù said Shoemaker. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to worry about starting them cattle and worry about someone not betting... The cattle industry ‚Äîit‚Äôs a big boost for them and they‚Äôve been needing it.‚Äù

Corey Cline, a bonded cattle dealer, echoed that sentiment. He said the recent surge is especially good news for producers across Nebraska and beyond who are finally seeing strong returns.

‚ÄúIt makes me feel really good for all the producers out here in Nebraska and all over the country that‚Äôs finally cashing in on some really good markets,‚Äù said Cline.

snippet.title: Kearney police officer injured in crash while responding to emergency
snippet.description:
A Kearney Police Department officer was injured in a collision with a Buffalo County Sheriff's Office patrol vehicle while responding to a medical emergency on the morning of September 11, 2025. The accident occurred at approximately 7:00 a.m. at the intersection of North Railroad Street and K Avenue, as both vehicles were traveling east.

Following the impact, the KPD patrol vehicle struck a curb and rolled, coming to rest on its driver side. The officer was trapped inside and required extrication with the assistance of Kearney Police Department officers, Kearney Volunteer Fire Department personnel, and CHI Good Samaritan Emergency Medical Services. The officer was transported to a local hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, where he was treated and released. The BCSO deputy involved in the accident was not injured.

The Nebraska State Patrol is conducting an investigation into the accident.

Read more: https://nebraska.tv/news/local/kearney-police-officer-injured-in-crash-while-responding-to-emergency#

snippet.title: Huskers Brace for Northwestern Run Attack; Rhule Disputes Notion of Lost Focus
snippet.description:
Nebraska head coach Matt Rhule pushed back on the idea that the Huskers lost focus in preparation for last week‚Äôs loss at Minnesota, saying his team ‚Äúdid not take our feet off the gas pedal‚Äù as they now turn their attention to Northwestern.

The response came after tight end Luke Lindemeier said Tuesday that Nebraska lost focus in the week leading up to the 24‚Äì6 setback in Minneapolis. Rhule disagreed, emphasizing that both last week and this week have featured strong practices.

‚ÄúI thought we had a great week of work,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúOur guys haven‚Äôt taken their foot off the gas.‚Äù

Nebraska will need that urgency against a Northwestern offense built on a physical ground game. The Wildcats are averaging 190 rushing yards per game, sixth best in the Big Ten. Rhule praised Northwestern‚Äôs offensive front and explosive running backs.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre unbelievably well-coached up front,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúTheir backs have great bursts and they‚Äôre as athletic as we‚Äôll see. They have home-run ability.‚Äù

The matchup puts pressure on a Nebraska defense ranked 15th in the Big Ten in rushing defense, allowing 157 yards per game. However, if the Huskers can keep the Wildcats behind the sticks, the advantage flips. Nebraska owns the nation‚Äôs top-ranked pass defense, while Northwestern enters with the No. 112 passing offense.

‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt let 1st-and-10 become 2nd-and-5,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going to come down to our ability to get off blocks and make tackles.‚Äù

Nebraska received mixed injury news entering the weekend. Starting right guard Rocco Spindler, who left the Minnesota game with a finger injury, is expected to play. Rhule called the decision a matter of pain tolerance and said Spindler practiced all week. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a baller,‚Äù Rhule said.

On the other side of the ledger, defensive back Malcolm Hartzog will miss the remainder of the season. He will redshirt after undergoing surgery for a core-muscle injury.

Nebraska (5‚Äì2, 2‚Äì2 Big Ten) and Northwestern (5‚Äì2, 3‚Äì1) kick off at 11 a.m. Saturday at Memorial Stadium.

snippet.title: Coach Rhule Urges Huskers to Play With ‚ÄòKiller Instinct‚Äô Against Houston Christian
snippet.description:
Nebraska coach Matt Rhule wants his team to carry a ‚Äúkiller instinct‚Äù into Saturday‚Äôs game against Houston Christian.

Previewing the matchup with the FCS opponent, Rhule pointed to another Nebraskan chasing history this weekend ‚Äî Omaha native Terence ‚ÄúBud‚Äù Crawford. The boxer is moving up multiple weight classes to face Canelo √Ålvarez in a bid to become the first male unified champion in three different divisions.

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt just sit there and hope that you get accolades,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúRisk it all. Risk it all to be great.‚Äù

Rhule said that mindset is what he wants from the Huskers all season. He emphasized playing a full 60 minutes and not letting an opponent gain life.

‚ÄúYou put away the people you‚Äôre supposed to put away,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre supposed to walk up to their A.D. and be like, ‚ÄòDon‚Äôt schedule them again.‚Äô That‚Äôs the mentality we‚Äôre supposed to have.‚Äù

Rhule reported no new injuries for Nebraska, noting his team remains healthy entering Week 3. While Houston Christian (1-1) is an FCS program, Rhule said the Huskers won‚Äôt overlook them.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre from Texas. They have quality players, good schemes, great coaching,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúSo we‚Äôre looking for the same 60 minutes of competition this week as well.‚Äù

Nebraska routed Akron 68-0 last week, its highest-scoring game since 2012. Rhule said he expects the Huskers to show the same energy against the Huskies.

snippet.title: Exclusive John Cook Interview Moments After Statue Revealed!
snippet.description:
Former Nebraska volleyball coach John Cook said it felt ‚Äúa little bit eerie‚Äù to see his newly unveiled bronze statue outside the Devaney Sports Center, but he credited the moment more to the program‚Äôs legacy than to himself.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so well done. I really admire the artists that do this,‚Äù Cook said, referencing world-renowned sculptor George Lundeen. ‚ÄúIt really doesn‚Äôt mean all that much for me. It‚Äôs more about Nebraska volleyball and all that we‚Äôve done here.  Nebraska‚Äôs the epicenter of volleyball in this country, and I think this is just a symbol of that.‚Äù

Cook announced his retirement on Jan. 29, 2025, after 25 seasons as Nebraska's head coach. Overall, Cook spent 32 years as a college head coach - seven at Wisconsin and 25 at Nebraska. He won four NCAA championships leading the Huskers.

Cook is the first non-football coach to receive a statue. He joins legendary football coaches Tom Osborne and Bob Devaney as the third Nebraska coach immortalized with a statue. Cook said Osborne called him the day before the unveiling.

‚ÄúHe always downplays it so much, that‚Äôs the way he is,‚Äù Cook said. ‚ÄúBut for me personally, he was one of my role models here. He was also the athletic director for four or five years and really helped me with the move to Devaney. To be recognized along with him means a lot.‚Äù

Cook also praised his successor, Dani Busboom Kelly, who took over the program this season.

‚ÄúTo me, it‚Äôs the greatest achievement of my coaching career ‚Äî to be able to hire a coach from Nebraska who played here, coached here, and won national championships, and then to come back as the head coach,‚Äù Cook said. ‚ÄúTo me, it‚Äôs my greatest accomplishment.‚Äù

Now living full-time in Wyoming, Cook said he enjoys life away from coaching but still feels a strong connection to the sport.

‚ÄúI love it. I can‚Äôt tell you how much I love it,‚Äù Cook said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve been back and forth because of things like this and doing some TV matches, which I really enjoy. It helps keep me a part of it.‚Äù

Cook recently sat on the other side of the camera, interviewing Busboom Kelly for a broadcast. He said the role came naturally.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to be your typical color analyst or interviewer because I know Dani,‚Äù Cook said. ‚ÄúI feel comfortable in asking her almost anything I wanted to try to get some more out of her for the fans to understand what it‚Äôs like to coach and how she feels. It was awesome.‚Äù

Speakers at the event included University of Nebraska President Jeffrey Gold, Nebraska Director of Athletics Troy Dannen, Nebraska Volleyball Head Coach Dani Busboom Kelly, and Cook himself.

After taking over the program in 2000, Cook guided the Huskers to four national championships, 12 NCAA Semifinal appearances, nine Big 12 titles, and five Big Ten titles. He achieved a career record of 883-176 (.834), the fifth-best winning percentage all-time for a Division I volleyball coach. Cook's record of 722-103 at Nebraska was the best winning percentage (.875) for any DI program from 2000-24.

With Cook at the helm, Nebraska produced numerous individual honors, including five Olympians, a Honda-Broderick Cup winner, three AVCA Division I National Players of the Year, 72 AVCA All-Americans, three Academic All-Americans of the Year, 25 Academic All-Americans, and 10 conference players of the year. Nebraska volleyball student-athletes combined for 88 all-conference awards and 155 academic all-conference honors in Cook's program.

snippet.title: Huskers Turn to True Freshman QB TJ Lateef after Dylan Raiola Injury Ahead of UCLA Matchup
snippet.description:
Nebraska will have to find a way to avoid back-to-back losses without its starting quarterback.

Head coach Matt Rhule confirmed Monday that sophomore quarterback Dylan Raiola is out for the season with a broken fibula. Raiola, who started 22 straight games in his Nebraska career, will undergo surgery this week.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not like it‚Äôs a ‚Äòbattle your way through it‚Äô type deal,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs going to have a chance for once to sit there and watch and learn. I know he‚Äôll be involved in game planning and ideas, and he‚Äôll rally around TJ.‚Äù

Raiola finishes the season with 2,000 passing yards, 18 touchdowns, and six interceptions through nine games.

True freshman TJ Lateef will step in as Nebraska‚Äôs new starting quarterback. Lateef saw limited action in blowout wins earlier this season against Akron and Houston Christian.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs really smart, always on time, knows the progressions, knows the checks ‚Äî you can trust him in those things,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs got amazing arm talent. He can spin it, he can run, he can move. He‚Äôs an excellent player, and I think everyone‚Äôs going to see him play really, really well.‚Äù

The start will be a homecoming for Lateef and five other Huskers who grew up in California. Nebraska travels to Pasadena to face UCLA under the lights at the Rose Bowl in primetime.

Rhule said UCLA, now 3-5, looks much improved after a midseason coaching change that elevated offensive coordinator Jerry Neuheisel to interim head coach.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really a tale of two seasons,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúYou take out the first part of the year ‚Äî they‚Äôre 3-2 in the Big Ten under Coach Skipper. They‚Äôve got things rolling, so it‚Äôll be an unbelievable battle, an unbelievable challenge.‚Äù

Another injury concern for Nebraska is offensive lineman Elijah Pritchett, who left the USC game early. Rhule said his status for UCLA will be a game-time decision, depending on pain tolerance.

snippet.title: Tar spot confirmed in western Nebraska
snippet.description:
Tar spot, a dangerous corn disease, has now been confirmed in western Nebraska. Experts warn it can reduce yields by up to 50%.

Agronomists are closely monitoring the spread of tar spot, a corn fungal disease, which is being detected in western Nebraska for the first time. Originally found in eastern states like Iowa and Minnesota, tar spot has gradually moved westward, with recent reports from Buffalo, Dawson and Custer counties.

Katelyn Duffy, CPI Precision Agronomy manager, highlighted the significance of the discovery. "We were the first to be able to identify tar spot [in the area] and also send it in for confirmation. It is a nasty disease that will can cause up to 50% yield loss if it's not caught soon enough and taken care of," she said.

To read more: https://nebraska.tv/news/local/tar-spot-disease-spreads-to-western-nebraska-raising-concerns-for-corn-yield#

snippet.title: Huskers set for first true road test at Maryland
snippet.description:
Nebraska will face its first true road game of the season this weekend as the Huskers (4-1) travel east to take on Maryland (4-1). Though they‚Äôve already played away from Lincoln once ‚Äî a win over Cincinnati in Kansas City ‚Äî head coach Matt Rhule said that game felt more like a home contest. To prepare for the long trip to the East Coast, Rhule said Nebraska is adjusting its typical travel schedule.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not a big Thursday operation,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúWe like to go on Fridays and keep our routine, but this is one time and the only time this year that we‚Äôll go out on Thursday, just because of the nature of being on the East Coast.‚Äù

The Huskers‚Äô defense will be tested by Maryland‚Äôs freshman quarterback Malik Washington, a former five-star recruit known for his ability to throw deep and extend plays. Washington has helped lead an offense averaging 31 points per game, with 257 yards passing and 93 yards rushing. ‚ÄúThey can run the football, but their passing game has really opened up,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre a pretty good pass defense, so it should be a good matchup.‚Äù

Nebraska‚Äôs offense continues to find balance behind quarterback Dylan Raiola. The Huskers are averaging 320 passing yards and 130 rushing yards per game. Both teams have excelled at protecting the football ‚Äî Nebraska is plus-six in turnover margin this season, while Maryland sits at plus-seven.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd rather be plus-one every game than plus-six on the year,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúThat gives you a chance to win.‚Äù

Rhule also highlighted several defensive standouts from the Michigan State game, including Elijah Jeudy‚Äôs first career sack and Deshaun Singleton‚Äôs two interceptions in the second quarter. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs one thing to not give the ball away, which we‚Äôre doing a pretty good job of,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúBut we‚Äôre also taking it away ‚Äî that‚Äôs playmakers stepping up.‚Äù

On the injury front, cornerback Malcolm Hartzog remains questionable after trying to test things out pregame last week. Rhule said Hartzog would be an ideal player to have against Maryland‚Äôs high-powered passing attack, but his status will be clearer after Tuesday‚Äôs practice. 

Nebraska and Maryland kick off Saturday in College Park at 2:30 PM CST, with both teams looking to stay in the hunt near the top of the Big Ten standings.

snippet.title: Nebraska Prepares for Prime-time Showdown with No. 23 USC as Rhule Signs Contract Extension
snippet.description:
The biggest news in college football on Thursday came out of Lincoln, where Nebraska head coach Matt Rhule signed a contract extension to remain with the Cornhuskers through 2032.

After finalizing the deal, Rhule quickly shifted focus to Saturday‚Äôs showdown against No. 23 USC at Memorial Stadium. The Huskers are looking to end a lengthy drought ‚Äî they‚Äôre 0‚Äì28 against AP Top 25 teams since 2016.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre playing a team this week coming off a bye, so you know you‚Äôre a little banged up, they‚Äôre fresh,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúYou better be dialed in ‚Äî and they‚Äôve been dialed in all week.‚Äù

Rhule‚Äôs extension, which he called a move about ‚Äústability,‚Äù sends a clear message of commitment to fans, players, and recruits.

‚ÄúI want to give this team everything I have and not be distracted with anything else,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúWhen they were able to get it done, we were able to get it done.‚Äù

Nebraska enters the weekend 6‚Äì2, its best eight-game start in nine years, but faces its toughest test yet. USC leads the Big Ten in total offense, averaging more than 530 yards and 42 points per game.

The Huskers counter with one of the league‚Äôs top pass defenses, ranking second in the conference, but will be challenged by Trojan quarterback Jayden Maiava, who has thrown for more than 2,100 yards and 19 touchdowns for the 5‚Äì2 Trojans.

On offense, Nebraska sophomore Dylan Raiola has tossed 17 touchdowns this season, while running back Emmett Johnson has surpassed 1,000 yards from scrimmage in just eight games.

Special teams could be a difference-maker. Nebraska leads the Big Ten and ranks third nationally in kickoff returns, averaging 32 yards per return. USC, meanwhile, ranks near the bottom of the nation in kick coverage, allowing 28 yards per return.

Game-time temperatures are expected to hover around 45 degrees at kickoff, with wind chills in the 30s ‚Äî conditions Rhule says his team is embracing.

Kickoff is set for 6:30 p.m. Saturday, November 1.

snippet.title: Nebraska Prepares for High-Stakes Matchup Against No. 23 USC
snippet.description:
Nebraska football faces a critical test Saturday night in prime time when No. 23 USC visits Memorial Stadium in a matchup that could determine the Huskers‚Äô postseason hopes.

The 6-2 Cornhuskers enter the game with their College Football Playoff aspirations still alive, while a loss would in all likelihood end their chances. Coach Matt Rhule said the team is focused on finishing games, not just competing.

‚ÄúI always want to come down the stretch of every year with a chance to make it in the College Football Playoff,‚Äù Rule said during his weekly Monday press conference. ‚ÄúThe entire focus this week is finishing, not just competing.‚Äù

Nebraska‚Äôs recent struggles include allowing Northwestern to come back from a 15-point deficit. Rhule emphasized the importance of closing out games when holding a lead.

On defense, the Huskers face a potent 5-2 USC offense led by quarterback Jayden Maiava, who excels at both passing and running the zone read. Rule, who has coached against USC coach Lincoln Riley at Temple and Baylor before last year's matchup, called him a ‚Äúbrilliant offensive mind‚Äù who will find ways to score.

The Nebraska game plan will rely on discipline, physicality, and tackling in space. Offensively, the Huskers aim to lean on running back Emmitt Johnson, who ranks second in the Big Ten with 837 rushing yards and leads the conference with 1,019 all-purpose yards. Johnson is the only Big Ten player this season to surpass 1,000 all-purpose yards.

Saturday night‚Äôs game will feature the Huskers in blackout uniforms, with Rhule noting the crowd at Memorial Stadium as a distinct advantage. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs truly a true 12th man,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBut again, it‚Äôs going to come down to blocking and tackling.‚Äù


Injury news for Nebraska includes starting right tackle Teddy Prochazka, who will miss the remainder of the season with a torn ACL. Porhaska also missed last year due to injury.

snippet.title: Huskers Football Holds Final Preseason Scrimmage
snippet.description:
Nebraska held its final preseason scrimmage on Saturday, as head coach Matt Rhule assessed where the Huskers stand two weeks ahead of their opener.

Rhule said he was pleased with the progress of his first-team units but stressed the need for more consistency from the reserves.

‚ÄúI feel really good about our first teams,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs which guys on the second team, which guys that are backups or even third team, which guys are going to step up. The quality of play dropped from the ones to the twos to the threes, and I don‚Äôt like that.‚Äù

Still, Rhule described the day as a ‚Äúvery successful‚Äù close to camp, noting the team is beginning to gel ahead of its Aug. 28 matchup against Cincinnati at Arrowhead Stadium.

snippet.title: Top Ranked Nebraska Sweeps Michigan to Open Big Ten Volleyball Play
snippet.description:
Top-ranked Nebraska opened Big Ten play with a sweep of Michigan on Sunday, improving to 11-0 with a 25-22, 25-10, 25-13 victory at the Bob Devaney Sports Center.

The Huskers, who entered the match unbeaten, controlled both sides of the ball after weathering an early surge from the Wolverines. Nebraska finished with 47 kills compared to Michigan‚Äôs 24, adding five service aces and 12 blocks.

Setter Bergen Reilly tallied 28 assists and moved into fifth place on Nebraska‚Äôs all-time assists list in the rally-scoring era, passing her head coach, Dani Busboom Kelly.

‚ÄúBeing a setter at Nebraska is such an honor, and it‚Äôs something that I‚Äôll never forget,‚Äù Reilly said. ‚ÄúI hope I‚Äôm only getting started too.‚Äù

Busboom Kelly praised her team‚Äôs composure after Michigan opened with energy. ‚ÄúI thought we played really well. Michigan came out blazing, but we stayed composed and forced a momentum shift,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt was just an overall really good performance on both sides of the ball.‚Äù

Freshman outside hitter Virginia Adriano added offensive firepower, hitting over .400 for the match, while libero Olivia Mauch anchored the back row with steady passing and out-of-system setting.

‚ÄúIt was a good, complete game by her,‚Äù Busboom Kelly said of Mauch, who has started at libero after taking over the position from Laney Choboy.

The Huskers stay at home for their next match when they host Maryland Saturday at 3 p.m. CST.

snippet.title: NTV News Live Stream
Huskers Stay Undefeated, Beating the Utes 3-1 After Dropping First Set at Home This Season
snippet.description:
Courtesy of Nebraska Athletics

The No. 1 Nebraska volleyball team bounced back from an opening set loss to win 3-1 over No. 22 Utah in front of 8,632 at John Cook Arena at the Bob Devaney Sports Center on Friday night.

The Huskers dropped the first set, 21-25, but recovered strong with 25-8, 25-18, 25-13 victories to improve to 7-0 on the season. Utah fell to 5-2.

Rebekah Allick tied her career high with 13 kills on .667 hitting, along with seven blocks. Andi Jackson posted nine kills and hit .375 with five blocks. Harper Murray also recorded nine kills. Taylor Landfair notched eight kills on .467 hitting and had two aces among her team-high 27 serve attempts. Allie Sczech came off the bench to provide six kills.

Nebraska hit .302 and held Utah to .063. Bergen Reilly recorded 32 assists and 18 digs, and Laney Choboy had 12 digs.

The Huskers had 12.5 blocks to 5.0 for Utah. NU had more kills (48-34) and digs (57-44). Both teams had three aces, but Nebraska made six fewer service errors.
