snippet.title: Coach DBK and All-American Setter Bergen Reilly Talk as Huskers Prepare for Utah and Grand Canyon
snippet.description:
Nebraska's All-American Setter Bergen Reilly says the Huskers‚Äô offense is finding its rhythm as the team prepares for Utah this weekend.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been working on consistency with hitters, and it‚Äôs been a fun offense to run,‚Äù Reilly said. ‚ÄúHopefully we can keep getting better and grow throughout the season.‚Äù

Reilly credited teammates for helping elevate her play, especially freshman setter Campbell. ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs beyond her years,‚Äù Reilly said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve even learned from her. She sets with full confidence and no fear.‚Äù

Head Coach Dani Busboom Kelly said she likes the progress her team has made, but passing remains an area for improvement.

‚ÄúOur passing has been solid, but there‚Äôs always room for growth,‚Äù Busboom Kelly said. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt expect perfection, but we want them to play free and know they can fail. That‚Äôs how you get better.‚Äù

Busboom Kelly emphasized the importance of enjoying wins rather than treating them with relief. ‚ÄúWhether it‚Äôs big or small, have fun and play free. The most important thing is what we‚Äôre doing right now,‚Äù she said.

#22 Utah, Nebraska‚Äôs next opponent, brings challenges. The Utes are known for strong serving and boast one of the nation‚Äôs top outside hitters. ‚ÄúUtah‚Äôs a really good serving team,‚Äù Busboom Kelly said. ‚ÄúWe have to be ready.‚Äù

The Huskers are 6-0 entering the matchup at the Devaney Center on Friday, September 9th. Saturday, September 10th, the Huskers host Grand Canyon.

snippet.title: NTV's Athlete of the Week: Hastings St. Cecilia Volleyball Senior MB Payton Sullivan
snippet.description:
Payton Sullivan loves Volleyball. The senior from Hastings St. Cecilia knew from a young age she‚Äôd be destined for big things.

‚ÄúThere is a memory I have, I went to my first-ever Nebraska game and said to my mom they‚Äôre really good at volleyball, I‚Äôm probably going to be good at volleyball,‚Äù said Payton Sullivan, St. Cecila senior.

Sullivan was right. The 6‚Äô1 senior middle has a .454 hitting percentage which ranks her second in all classes and first in class C.

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs going to see four hands all the time, but because of her athleticism and how hard she works she knows how to swing high,‚Äù said St. Cecilia head coach Kelan Schumacher.

Sullivan‚Äôs hitting ability was on full display as the Wayne State commit garnered her 1000th career kill.

‚ÄúAs a middle hitter its not super easy to get 1000 kills. She works so hard and its super impressive,‚Äù said Shumacher.

‚ÄúSince I was young, I‚Äôve always wanted to be the best I can be, so I‚Äôve put in a lot of hours in the gym plus the ability to be able to jump a little bit which helps me have better court vision,‚Äù said Sullivan.

Sullivan and her team are one win away from returning to the state playoffs.

snippet.title: Huskers Open Season Against Pitt in Showcase at PBA
snippet.description:
Nebraska volleyball opens its season in historic fashion, playing its first-ever match at Pinnacle Bank Arena on  Friday in the AVCA First Serve Showcase. The top-ranked Huskers face a stiff test against No. 3 Pittsburgh, which is coming off a 33-2 season and its fourth straight NCAA semifinal appearance.

The Panthers return AVCA National Player of the Year Olivia Babcock and a roster that coach Dan Fisher has bolstered with new additions.

Nebraska enters a new era under first-year head coach Dani Busboom Kelly, who takes over after two decades under John Cook. Busboom Kelly is no stranger to Fisher, having faced him annually while coaching at Louisville.

‚ÄúI just think we made each other better,‚Äù Fisher said. ‚ÄúThey exposed stuff that we didn‚Äôt see against some other teams, and I think we were able to do the same against them.‚Äù

The matchup is steeped in history, as Nebraska has won all 14 previous meetings against Pitt. But this time, the Panthers bring one of the nation‚Äôs toughest serving and grittiest defensive squads.

Nebraska players said the environment inside PBA feels like December volleyball.

‚ÄúA lot of us were saying it felt like we‚Äôre in December already, like it really feels like a Final Four environment, which is cool,‚Äù captain junior setter Bergen Reilly said. ‚ÄúWe know the fans are going to bring it, so that‚Äôll make it even better.‚Äù

The Huskers won‚Äôt get much of a break. On Sunday, they‚Äôll face No. 6 Stanford in another top-10 showdown.

‚ÄúWhen you get to December, you‚Äôre only playing the best of the best,‚Äù Busboom Kelly said. ‚ÄúYou have to challenge yourself. Might as well start early in the season and be prepared.‚Äù

snippet.title: Huskers Ready for Rivalry with Penn State in First Big Ten Road Test
snippet.description:
John Cook‚Äôs legendary run with Nebraska volleyball ended last season in familiar fashion ‚Äî deep in December, but just short of another title.

The four-time national champion retired after the Huskers fell to Penn State in the 2024 national semifinals. The Nittany Lions went on to defeat Louisville in the final under head coach Dani Busboom Kelly, who is now in her first season leading the Nebraska program.

Busboom Kelly has the Huskers off to a 12-0 start, including 2-0 in Big Ten play, as they prepare for their first road test of the season: a trip to Penn State for the 13th match of the year.

Senior captains Rebekah Allick and Bergen Reilly aren‚Äôt hiding what the matchup means.

‚ÄúI got a grudge, so I want to kick some butt,‚Äù Allick said. 

‚ÄúGames like this always have implications for the postseason," Reilly said.

Allick said consistency will be key against Penn State‚Äôs All-American Kennedy Martin.

‚ÄúFirst and second set, that kind of attack, they‚Äôre going to hit everything probably at full force,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúBut in the fourth and fifth set, if it goes long, you start to see tendencies and what hitters are most comfortable with.‚Äù

Reilly echoed the stakes.

‚ÄúWe know what our goals are, and that‚Äôs a Big Ten championship and a national championship,‚Äù Reilly said. ‚ÄúOur offense has been flowing, and that allows me to be more aggressive. But we know Penn State is one of the loudest gyms in the country, and we have to be ready for that.‚Äù

Busboom Kelly, who lost twice to Penn State last year with Louisville, said motivation won‚Äôt be an issue.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd say we‚Äôre pretty motivated,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs kind of a chip-on-our-shoulder week.‚Äù

Nebraska‚Äôs trip doesn‚Äôt end in State College. The Huskers head to Rutgers the following day, but for now, all eyes are on the rivalry match.

First serve is scheduled for 7 p.m. Friday on FOX.

snippet.title: Matt Rhule Previews Michigan, Speaks on QB Dylan Raiola's Success, and Being at Bud Crawford fight
snippet.description:
Matt Rhule met with the media ahead of Nebraska‚Äôs showdown with Michigan and said his team has worked hard through the first three games to be ready for the Big Ten grind. He praised Michigan‚Äôs offensive line as one of the nation‚Äôs best and said quarterback Bryce Underwood will face some of the same first-time challenges Dylan Raiola went through last year. Rhule called Raiola more than ready for the league, pointing to his leadership, ability to check into the right plays, and even sharing how after the Houston Christian game Raiola went home and texted him a video breaking down plays on a whiteboard.

He confirmed DBs like Malcolm Hartzog will be available after precautionary absences and said red zone struggles are a teaching point this week. He credited Nebraska‚Äôs offensive balance for avoiding three-and-outs in recent games and said practicing against Tony White‚Äôs defense has prepared Raiola for the pressure he‚Äôll see from Michigan.

Rhule also described the atmosphere at the Terence Crawford fight in Las Vegas as the best sporting event he‚Äôs ever attended and reflected on how the team bonds around shared commitments. He closed by noting that non-conference games felt like preseason, but the Big Ten is here now and Nebraska has to prove itself against ranked opponents on national TV.

snippet.description:
Nebraska Volleyball Sweeps Oregon to Stay Only Undefeated Team in D1 NCAAVB Lincoln, NEB ‚Äî Press Release Courtesy of Nebraska Athletics-

The No. 1 Nebraska volleyball team fought past Oregon for a 25-21, 25-20, 25-12 victory on Sunday in front of a crowd of 8,495 at John Cook Arena at the Bob Devaney Sports Center.

Nebraska hit .405 and held Oregon to .162, as the Huskers improved to 22-0 (12-0 Big Ten). The Huskers have won 40 sets in a row and have swept 13 matches in a row.

Taylor Landfair led all players with 10 kills and hit .400. Harper Murray added nine kills (.391) and nine digs, and Virginia Adriano had eight kills (.500) and three blocks. Rebekah Allick and Andi Jackson each had five kills with five and three blocks, respectively.

Bergen Reilly dished out 26 assists with five digs. Laney Choboy had five digs and six assists, and Olivia Mauch had five digs and three assists. Teraya Sigler also had five digs.

Nebraska had a 39-35 advantage in kills, 9-3 in blocks and 32-28 in digs.

Set 1: Oregon held a 3-1 lead before Nebraska scored eight of the next 10 points to go up 9-5. The Ducks answered with a 5-1 run to tie the score at 10-10. Allick and Murray tallied kills for a 13-11 lead, but Oregon regained a 16-15 lead. An ace by Jackson and kill by Landfair put NU on top, 18-17. Adriano added a kill, and an ace by Sigler made it 20-18. Murray recorded a kill and a solo block for set point, and Jackson finished it off 25-21 with a kill.

Set 2: The Ducks put forth another strong effort in taking a 12-11 lead. Jackson had a kill and Murray served an ace to help NU go up 14-12, but the Ducks went back in front, 17-16. Allick had a kill and a block with Adriano before Adriano added a kill, as the Huskers built a 21-17 lead after a 5-0 run served by Sigler. Murray pounded two more kills as the Huskers grabbed set point, 24-19, and the Huskers won 25-20.

Set 3: Adriano had two kills, and Mauch served an ace as part of a 4-0 run that made it 5-1 Huskers. Landfair provided two kills and Allick another as Nebraska went ahead 9-4. A five-point run served by Reilly made it 23-11 Huskers with Adriano tallying a kill and two blocks with Allick, and Adriano and Allick finished off the match, 25-12, with kills. Nebraska hit .500 in the final set (15-1-28) and held Oregon to .037 (7-6-27).

Up Next: Nebraska hosts Illinois on Thursday at 7 p.m. in John Cook Arena at the Bob Devaney Sports Center.

snippet.title: Huskers Football Enters Week One of the Season
snippet.description:
Nebraska football has two practices left in Lincoln, including one today, before opening its season Thursday night against Cincinnati at Arrowhead Stadium in Kansas City.

Head coach Matt Rhule will address the media following Tuesday‚Äôs practice, but Monday belonged to his coordinators. Both sides of the ball showed confidence while acknowledging the nerves that come with a season opener.

‚ÄúJitters can be good,‚Äù offensive coordinator Dana Holgorsen said. ‚ÄúIt just means the guys are ready to go.‚Äù

The offensive line has drawn the most attention this camp, with Nebraska praising its depth and flexibility.

‚ÄúThe rotation at tackle is something I‚Äôve never had the luxury to do,‚Äù Holgorsen said. ‚ÄúHaving five quality guys who can go out there and play is a huge advantage.‚Äù

Quarterback Dylan Raiola, who is entering year two as the starter, said he feels prepared after a long camp and months of offseason work.

Although Raiola has been to Arrowhead Stadium many times as a fan, he said Thursday‚Äôs stage will be different.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a different mission ‚Äî to go down there and win a football game,‚Äù Raiola said. ‚ÄúObviously, my mindset will be different. The guys will be juiced up and ready to go.‚Äù

Raiola, who has a friendship with Chiefs quarterback Patrick Mahomes, even sought his advice on equipment for the game.

‚ÄúI asked Pat if I needed to wear seven-studded cleats,‚Äù Raiola said. ‚ÄúHe said no ‚Äî the field‚Äôs in perfect shape. Just play ball.‚Äù

Kickoff between Nebraska and Cincinnati is set for just after 8 p.m. Thursday at Arrowhead Stadium, with more than 74,000 fans expected in attendance.

snippet.title: Three Husker Volleyball Players Earn Big Ten Weekly Honors
snippet.description:
Press release courtesy of Nebraska Athletics:

Three Nebraska volleyball student-athletes were awarded weekly honors from the Big Ten Conference on Tuesday. With just three Big Ten teams beginning their season over the past weekend, the Huskers collected three of the four awards.

Bergen Reilly was named Big Ten Setter of the Week for the 10th time in her career; Rebekah Allick was named Big Ten Defensive Player of the Week for the third time, and Virginia Adriano was chosen Big Ten Freshman of the Week for the first time.

Reilly had 10.86 assists per set and 2.71 digs per set in leading the Huskers to two top 10 wins over No. 3 Pitt and No. 6 Stanford. Reilly opened the season with a double-double of 40 assists and 10 digs in a 3-1 win against Pitt. She also had three blocks, one kill and one ace. The two-time Big Ten Setter of the Year followed up on Sunday with 36 assists and nine digs along with four kills and three blocks in a sweep of Stanford. Reilly set the Huskers to a .385 hitting percentage, Nebraska's best hitting percentage against a ranked team since 2016.

Allick posted 1.71 blocks per set to go along with 2.86 kills per set and a .406 hitting percentage in the Huskers' two wins at the AVCA First Serve. She began the season with seven blocks and nine kills in the win against Pitt and recorded five more blocks with 11 kills on .600 hitting in the sweep of Stanford. Allick was named MVP of Sunday's match against the Cardinal and, along with libero Laney Choboy, was named to the AVCA All-First Serve Team on Tuesday.

In her first ever collegiate match against No. 3 Pitt, Adriano posted six kills and three blocks, which helped the Big Red hold Pitt to a .111 hitting percentage in the 3-1 Husker win.

snippet.title: Hastings St. Cecilia Wins First Softball State Title
snippet.description:
Hastings St. Cecilia captured its first state softball championship in school history, walking off No. 6 seed Central City in the bottom of the seventh to win the NSAA Class C title.

The top-seeded Bluehawks led most of the game before the Bison rallied in the top of the seventh to take a brief lead. But St. Cecilia stayed composed, setting the stage for Maddison Bauer, who delivered the game-winning hit.

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt lie, I was a little nervous, but I knew we were going to pull through,‚Äù Bauer said. ‚ÄúI knew I had to hit it because I didn‚Äôt want to let down my team. I love everyone so much, and they‚Äôve always been there for me.‚Äù

The championship marked a milestone for the program and the school.

‚ÄúWe made history,‚Äù senior pitcher Audrey Rossow, who earned the win, said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve never had a state championship for softball, so we‚Äôll always be up there. It means so much right now.‚Äù

Head coach Matt Rossow echoed the emotion.

‚ÄúAbsolutely amazing,‚Äù Rossow said. ‚ÄúThese girls fought for the kids who started going to state seven years ago. They just wanted to win one for the program.‚Äù

Players and coaches credited the school community for helping push them across the finish line.

‚ÄúSt. Cecilia fans, we appreciate the support,‚Äù Rossow said. ‚ÄúThey helped us through.‚Äù

Now, the team from Hastings will be remembered forever ‚Äî as state champions.

#hastings #hastingsstcecilia #nsaa #nebpreps #nebraskasoftball

snippet.title: Matt Rhule Speaks On Penn State Head Coaching Rumors,  "I Love Nebraska"
snippet.description:
Nebraska football coach Matt Rhule addressed national speculation linking him to the Penn State head coaching job during his press conference Monday to open Minnesota Week.

‚ÄúI love it here. It‚Äôs awesome,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúTroy [Dannen, Nebraska AD] and I are in constant, constant communication about this program and where we‚Äôre headed. You know, Troy and I understand the steps that you need to take to make us Big Ten champions and national champions. This place is elite.‚Äù

Rhule, a Penn State alumnus, said he has a deep respect for his alma mater and Athletic Director Pat Kraft, but emphasized his commitment to Nebraska and the program he is building in Lincoln.

Rhule is in the third year of an eight-year deal worth up to $74 million. He earns about $7.5 million this season and is set to make around $10 million annually at the peak of his contract. If Nebraska fires him, his buyout would be $49 million. If he leaves voluntarily, the buyout drops to $5 million this year and decreases by $1 million each subsequent year.

Looking ahead, Rhule said his focus remains on Nebraska‚Äôs future, including a 2027 recruiting class currently ranked in the top ten nationally. ‚ÄúPlayers all across the country want to come here. We have the best facilities. We have elite fans. I‚Äôm really happy here and excited to get going this week on Minnesota,‚Äù he said.

Rhule also shared that his family is thriving in Lincoln. His wife is a local business owner, and their children enjoy school and the community. He said his decision to come to Nebraska was driven by two factors: the community and the opportunity to rebuild the program into a powerhouse.

This will be a developing story throughout the season.

snippet.title: Powerful Perseverance
snippet.description:
Imagine having to be so exact at what you do it‚Äôs down to the thousandth of a second whether or not you succeed.

Now picture doing that while going more than 140 miles per hour.

One young man from Holbrook, Nebraska does all of that, but first he has to move from one set of wheels to another.

As Justin Hamel slides into the driver's seat, he is thankful for the time he has taken to strengthen his arms so he can easily lift himself out of his wheelchair and into his race car. Hamel's life changed forever after a motorcycle accident left him paralyzed from the chest down. But his faith, family and the will to win has kept him in the fast lane.

When he's not going full throttle on the racetrack, Hamel is working on his other business, Full Throttle Rifle Company.

Hamel knows his way around the drag strip... and his race car... so much so he has the trophies to prove it. In bracket racing, your opponent isn't the car next to you, it's yourself and your ability to hit your time down to a fraction of a second.

And Hamel knows a thing or two about competing with himself, as he's worked hard for years to get himself to where he is today, rehabbing through a life-changing injury to becoming a champion driver, time after time.

Whether it‚Äôs racing his car, re-designing guns, or working on trucks with his dad and brother, Justin Hamel doesn‚Äôt let being in a wheelchair slow him down.

snippet.title: Huskers Football Memorial Stadium Light and Drone Show vs. Akron
snippet.description:
NOTE: Due to YouTube Upload copyright for shorts, Thunderstruck has been replaced.

Nebraska lit up Memorial Stadium on Saturday night, scoring 68 points in a rout while the Akron Zips scored ZIP points. It‚Äôs Big Red‚Äôs most points scored since dropping 73 on Idaho State in 2012. While the offensive explosion piled up 728 total yards ‚Äî the eighth-highest total in school history ‚Äî the story of the night belonged to the Huskers finding new playmakers.

Junior tight end Luke Lindenmeyer caught a 10-yard touchdown in the second quarter, his first career score, before celebrating postgame with an engagement. 

Not long after, redshirt freshman receiver Quinn Clark broke free for a 37-yard touchdown reception, also the first of his young career.

On defense, true freshman Kade Pietrzak made his debut felt early. His first career tackle came in the backfield, resulting in a safety that gave Nebraska a 9-0 lead and marked the team‚Äôs first safety since last year‚Äôs opener.

Backup quarterback TJ Lateef, another true freshman, provided a spark in the second half. He went 6-of-7 passing for 128 yards and capped his night with his first career rushing touchdown.
All of it came behind a record-setting night from quarterback Dylan Raiola, who completed 24-of-31 passes for a career-high 364 yards and four touchdowns, extending his streak to a school-record 20 straight completions.

The shutout marked Nebraska‚Äôs first since the 2009 Holiday Bowl when they beat Arizona 33-0. They look to advance to 3-0 when they host Houston Christian on Saturday, the 13th, with an 11 am kickoff.

snippet.title: Huskers Set Sights on Washington and No. 12 Purdue
snippet.description:
The top-ranked Nebraska volleyball team returned home unbeaten after a statement weekend on the road, sweeping No. 16 Penn State and Rutgers to move to 14-0.

Nebraska opened the weekend with a decisive sweep of Penn State, allowing just 34 points across three sets ‚Äî one of the most dominant wins in program history. The Huskers followed that performance with another sweep at Rutgers, where a record-setting crowd of 8,000 fans packed the arena ‚Äî the largest volleyball attendance ever in New Jersey.

Head coach Dani Busboom Kelly said the trip offered a strong test early in Big Ten play ‚Äî and her team delivered.

‚ÄúWe played great on both sides of the ball,‚Äù Busboom Kelly said. ‚ÄúOur defense was sharp, our offense was clicking, and we got great contributions from a lot of players.‚Äù

Freshman Manaia Ogbechie said the energy on the East Coast trip caught the team by surprise.

‚ÄúIt was so loud,‚Äù Ogbechie said. ‚ÄúThere was so much support from everybody, and it‚Äôs amazing how much people care about our team and the sport.‚Äù

The weekend also provided valuable experience for Nebraska‚Äôs young roster learning to handle Big Ten pressure.

‚ÄúEvery match feels like a battle,‚Äù freshman Teraya Sigler said. ‚ÄúPeople are yelling, heckling ‚Äî but you just have to block it out and play your game.‚Äù

Now, Nebraska turns its attention to a home match against Washington on Friday before heading to West Lafayette to face No. 12 Purdue on Sunday ‚Äî a quick turnaround that Busboom Kelly called ‚Äúa first.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll practice at Purdue on Saturday since we play early Sunday,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not our normal routine, but we want to get comfortable in their gym.‚Äù

The Huskers will host a red-white stripe-out at the Bob Devaney Sports Center on Friday night. Fans are encouraged to check their ticket sections and wear the corresponding color to show their ‚ÄúBig Red‚Äù pride.

#Huskers #NebraskaVolleyball #GBR #TerayaSigler #danibusboomkelly #ManaiaOgbechie

snippet.title: Huskers' Defense Focused on Fundamentals Ahead of Arrowhead Opener
snippet.description:
Nebraska‚Äôs defense is sharpening fundamentals and building depth as the Huskers prepare for their season opener next Thursday against Cincinnati at Arrowhead Stadium.

Defensive coordinator John Butler said the past two scrimmages have provided a valuable test. ‚ÄúI think the scrimmage has been great because it‚Äôs iron on iron. We‚Äôve got two good units, a good offense, and a good defense,‚Äù Butler said. He emphasized the importance of playing aggressively without losing focus downfield, and said early mistakes have been corrected through fundamentals.

For position coaches, the goal is developing complete players. Outside linebackers and defensive linemen are learning to balance rushing the passer with stopping the run and defending against complex offensive schemes. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an all-around game,‚Äù inside linebackers coach Phil Simpson said. ‚ÄúWe stand consistent with the fundamentals, and that‚Äôs going to carry us over to the first game.‚Äù

Defensive line coach Terry Bradden noted his personal ties to Kansas City and the excitement surrounding the Arrowhead opener. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a beautiful stadium,‚Äù Bradden said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs one day at a time, focus on the small things, but it‚Äôs going to be a great experience.‚Äù

Linebackers and other players also expressed enthusiasm about playing in Kansas City. Senior linebacker Dasan McCullough said, ‚ÄúFor my last year to be able to play my season opener in KC against Cincinnati, where I was born, it‚Äôs going to be huge. I have a lot of people coming.‚Äù Many players noted that family and friends are clamoring for tickets, underscoring the excitement and support from the Big Red Kingdom.

With only 10 days until kickoff, Nebraska‚Äôs defense says it is ready to translate practice intensity into game-day performance.

snippet.title: Voters reject law enforcement center bond
snippet.description:
Buffalo County voters have decisively rejected a $72 million proposal for a new law enforcement center, with 67% voting against and 33% in favor. The proposed center aimed to address space concerns by relocating the Buffalo County Sheriff's Office and Kearney Police Department to a new building with over double the current amount of space. Buffalo County Sheriff Neil Miller said with the bond being rejected, they are in a tough spot. "We didn't really talk about a plan B or plan C. But we'll get together and kind of look at other alternatives that we can do and discuss what that might look like."

snippet.title: Huskers Playoff Hopes go Dark with Loss to USC on Blackout Night
snippet.description:
On a blackout night at Memorial Stadium, the 409th consecutive sellout in Lincoln, Nebraska‚Äôs College Football Playoff hopes went dark. The Huskers‚Äô chances are basically 0% now after losing their third game of the year, a 21-17 loss to No. 23 USC. Nebraska is now 0-29 against AP Top 25 teams since 2016.

‚ÄúThis is a very bitter pill for us to swallow,‚Äù head coach Matt Rhule said. ‚ÄúWe had a lot of opportunities to win the football game. I don‚Äôt think anyone‚Äôs held them to 21 points very often. They‚Äôre explosive and we had some really good, valiant moments, but we lost the game, so we‚Äôll have to get better.‚Äù

The Huskers led 14-6 at halftime, but their offense went quiet after quarterback Dylan Raiola left with a right ankle injury early in the second half. He didn‚Äôt return, and Nebraska scored just three points the rest of the way.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think you can put a guy out there who can‚Äôt defend and protect himself,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúThe trainers didn‚Äôt want him to go out there, but they didn‚Äôt say no he can‚Äôt. They just kind of said he shouldn‚Äôt be out there, so I told Dylan I love you too much to ask you to play when you‚Äôre hurt like this.‚Äù

Running back Emmett Johnson did his part, carrying 29 times for 165 yards and a touchdown. It was his fifth 100-yard game of the season, putting him over 1,000 yards on the year.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm thankful to God for the opportunity to do that and give credit to my line,‚Äù Johnson said. ‚ÄúBut that doesn‚Äôt mean anything if we don‚Äôt win the game. That‚Äôs all that matters to me.‚Äù

Defensively, Nebraska held USC nearly 200 yards under its season average, giving up just 337 total yards and only 135 through the air ‚Äî the Trojans‚Äô lowest passing total in nearly seven years. Still, big plays proved costly.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to sound like we‚Äôre victims of circumstance,‚Äù defensive back Ceyair Wright said. ‚ÄúAt the end of the day, don‚Äôt hang your head. We had a good fight.‚Äù

On a night that was supposed to be a statement for Nebraska football, the Huskers instead fell short. Rhule, who signed a contract extension earlier in the week, is now 0-7 against ranked opponents at Nebraska.

Next up, Nebraska travels to Pasadena to face UCLA. The 3-5 Bruins are coming off a bye week, just like USC was this week.

snippet.title: Huskers Score 24 Unanswered Points in 2nd Half to Beat Michigan State.
snippet.description:
‚ÄúTake their soul.‚Äù

Those were the words of Nebraska wide receiver Jacory Barney Jr. to his teammates at halftime Saturday, when the Huskers led Michigan State 14-7. In recent years, Nebraska teams have let opponents hang around in close games. This group refused to let that happen.

After falling behind 21-14 in the third quarter, Dylan Raiola and the Huskers responded with 24 unanswered points to pull away for a 38-27 win at Memorial Stadium. The victory improved Nebraska to 4-1 overall and 1-1 in Big Ten play.

‚ÄúIt felt good to come out here and get that taste out of our mouths,‚Äù Barney said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been waiting for a while to play again, and now we‚Äôre on to next week.‚Äù

Head coach Matt Rhule called it a complete team win. Jamir Conn blocked a punt that Carter Nelson returned for a touchdown, while Nebraska finished with a plus-three turnover margin on the day.

‚ÄúThese are the types of plays that make this season feel different,‚Äù Raiola said. ‚ÄúWe weren‚Äôt going to let it slip away. You train all offseason for that moment, and when it‚Äôs there, you have to take it.‚Äù

Running back Emmett Johnson continued to lead the offense, posting more than 100 yards from scrimmage and scoring three rushing touchdowns.

On defense, DeShon Singleton recorded two first-half interceptions, while Elijah Jeudy notched his first career sack.

‚ÄúGo out and ball, Singleton said. It‚Äôs hunt or be hunted, and we‚Äôre hunting.‚Äù

Veteran linebacker Javin Wright, in his seventh year with the program, said the belief within this team feels different from years past.

‚ÄúNo knock on the other teams I‚Äôve been with,‚Äù Wright said. ‚ÄúBut the culture inside this locker room and on the sidelines ‚Äî there‚Äôs just a belief that we‚Äôre going to win, whether we‚Äôre up or down. There‚Äôs never a doubt.‚Äù

Nebraska will carry that confidence into its first true road game of the season next week at Maryland (4-1), which suffered its first loss of the year to Washington on Saturday.

snippet.title: Nebraska Football Loses on the Road at Minnesota
snippet.description:
Press Release Courtesy of Nebraska Athletics-

No. 25 Nebraska was held to a season-low 213 yards, while Minnesota‚Äôs Darius Taylor rushed for 148 yards and a touchdown in Minnesota‚Äôs 24-6 victory over Nebraska Friday night.

The Huskers (5-2, 2-2 Big Ten) got only a pair of Kyle Cunanan field goals, as their two-game win streak was snapped. Dylan Raiola completed 16-of-24 passes for 172 yards but was sacked nine times and NU managed just 36 yards rushing.

Minnesota (4-2, 3-1 Big Ten) was efficient offensively, as the Gophers rushed for 186 yards while Drake Lindsey completed 16-of-20 passes for 153 yards and a touchdown and rushed for another score.

Nebraska struck first, as the Huskers marched 70 yards on 12 plays to set up Cunanan‚Äôs 33-yard field goal on the final play of the first quarter. Raiola found Luke Lindenmeyer on a 26-yard completion to get the Huskers to near midfield. NU continued to march, as a Gopher pass interference call and a 10-yard catch from Nyziah Hunter got the Huskers to the red zone. A four-yard run by Emmett Johnson on first down put the Huskers at the 10-yard line, but the drive stalled, forcing a field goal.

Johnson totaled nearly 100 all-purpose yards, as he rushed for 63 yards on 14 carries while catching five passes for 37 yards.

Minnesota came right back, needing just four plays to go 90 yards to take a 7-3 lead. The Gophers had 90 of their 154 first-half yards on the drive, highlighted by a 71-yard run by Taylor to the Husker 1-yard line before Lindsey‚Äôs sneak capped the scoring drive.

Nebraska trimmed the Gopher lead to 7-6 midway through the second quarter after Cunanan‚Äôs second field goal of the day, this one from 30 yards. A career-long 43-yard reception from Quinn Clark and an 11-yard rush from Johnson gave the Huskers first and 10 at the Minnesota 11, but the Gopher defense stiffened, and NU had to settle for a field goal.

Minnesota extended its lead to 14-6 following a 14-play, 98-yard march that took nearly nine minutes off the clock. The Huskers had a chance to get the Gophers off the field, as Minnesota went for it on fourth-and-three from the NU 34. Lindsey‚Äôs pass was incomplete, but a defensive holding call kept the drive alive. Two plays later, Lindsey found Lemeke Brockington for the 20-yard touchdown pass.

The Gophers stretched the lead to 21-6 after a Taylor 1-yard run capped a six-play, 62-yard drive. A costly Husker defensive penalty kept Minnesota‚Äôs drive alive before Lindsey found Jalen Smith on a 35-yard catch and run to set up the score. Minnesota extended the margin to 24-6 on a 30-yard field goal from Brady Denaburg with 5:14 left for the final score.

The Huskers will return to action next Saturday, as Nebraska host Northwestern at Memorial Stadium. The kickoff time and network will be determined following Saturday‚Äôs games.

snippet.title: Huskers Shut Out Akron 68-0!
snippet.description:
Nebraska lit up Memorial Stadium on Saturday night, scoring 68 points in a rout while the Akron Zips scored ZIP points. It‚Äôs Big Red‚Äôs most points scored since dropping 73 on Idaho State in 2012. While the offensive explosion piled up 728 total yards ‚Äî the eighth-highest total in school history ‚Äî the story of the night belonged to the Huskers finding new playmakers.

Junior tight end Luke Lindenmeyer caught a 10-yard touchdown in the second quarter, his first career score, before celebrating postgame with an engagement. 

Not long after, redshirt freshman receiver Quinn Clark broke free for a 37-yard touchdown reception, also the first of his young career.

On defense, true freshman Kade Pietrzak made his debut felt early. His first career tackle came in the backfield, resulting in a safety that gave Nebraska a 9-0 lead and marked the team‚Äôs first safety since last year‚Äôs opener.

Backup quarterback TJ Lateef, another true freshman, provided a spark in the second half. He went 6-of-7 passing for 128 yards and capped his night with his first career rushing touchdown.
All of it came behind a record-setting night from quarterback Dylan Raiola, who completed 24-of-31 passes for a career-high 364 yards and four touchdowns, extending his streak to a school-record 20 straight completions.

The shutout marked Nebraska‚Äôs first since the 2009 Holiday Bowl when they beat Arizona 33-0. They look to advance to 3-0 when they host Houston Christian on Saturday, the 13th, with an 11 am kickoff.

snippet.title: Cornhuskers Aim for 3-0 Start Against Houston Christian
snippet.description:
LINCOLN, Neb. ‚Äî Nebraska looks to improve to 3-0 for the third straight season when it hosts Houston Christian on Saturday. It will mark the first-ever meeting between the Huskers and the Huskies.

Quarterback Dylan Raiola is coming off a historic performance. Raiola completed 20 consecutive passes spanning the Cincinnati and Akron games, breaking a school record that had stood for 51 years. The previous mark was 15.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs incredible,‚Äù offensive lineman Rocco Spindler said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a guy that knows ball and he trusts us too. If we see something, he‚Äôs willing to change the protection and trust our eyes. He can make crazy throws. Dylan‚Äôs a great quarterback, leader, friend‚Äîeverything. We‚Äôre extremely thankful for him.‚Äù

Houston Christian enters the matchup averaging nearly 400 yards per game, with 173 of those through the air. Nebraska defensive coordinator John Butler said his unit will be prepared.

‚ÄúNo matter who it is‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs Cincinnati, Akron, Houston Christian, Michigan or Michigan State‚Äîwe have a healthy respect for them,‚Äù Butler said. ‚ÄúA lot of what we do on the practice field is making sure we‚Äôre executing our defense. Fundamentally, physically, effort-wise, and execution-wise, we‚Äôre on point. I thought today was a pretty good practice, so I think we have their attention.‚Äù

The Huskers are in the middle of a four-game homestand. Saturday‚Äôs kickoff at Memorial Stadium is set for just after 11 a.m.

snippet.title: Nebraska Men's Basketball ends preseason with win over Midland
snippet.description:
Nebraska men‚Äôs basketball closed out its preseason schedule with a dominant 91-50 win over Midland on Monday night inside Pinnacle Bank Arena.

Coming off a scrimmage win over a top-10 BYU team last week, head coach Fred Hoiberg said he didn‚Äôt want a letdown against the in-state NAIA opponent. Early turnovers tested the Huskers‚Äô focus, but they quickly found their rhythm.

Brandon Frager provided the spark on both ends, hitting six 3-pointers and making a highlight-reel block in transition that he called his favorite play of the game. Nebraska went 15-for-44 from behind the arc (34%) and shot 44% overall from the field.

After a close start, the Huskers built a 20-point lead by halftime and never looked back.

‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt want to overextend Rink in this game,‚Äù Hoiberg said. ‚ÄúIt was good to get Ugnius out there for a stretch and got everybody on the floor. It was a good preseason for us, and now the fun begins.‚Äù

Hoiberg praised his team‚Äôs physicality and defensive adjustments, noting the group‚Äôs improvement in communication during media timeouts.

Nebraska will open the regular season at Pinnacle Bank Arena on Monday, Nov. 3, against West Georgia.

snippet.title: NSAA Class A Girls State Golf Championship Results 2025
snippet.description:
On a cold, gray October afternoon at Riverside Golf Club, the competition was anything but dull as the NSAA awarded its first state championship of the new school year. The Class A Girls State Golf Championship came down to the final holes ‚Äî and a Columbus senior came out on top.

Molly Goc of Columbus captured the individual state title with a two-day total of 149, edging Lincoln Southwest freshman Naryn Kim by one stroke. Kim finished second with a 150, while her teammate, senior Eden Larson, placed third at 151.

‚ÄúIt means a lot,‚Äù Goc said after the win. ‚ÄúAll the hard work that I put in has finally paid off and it feels amazing. I plan to go to Wayne to play golf.‚Äù

In the team competition, Omaha Marian successfully defended its state championship, posting a total score of 636 to claim back-to-back titles. Omaha Westside finished runner-up for the second year in a row with a score of 669.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôve got a state championship trophy ‚Äî their second in two years ‚Äî and we‚Äôre really proud of their effort this year,‚Äù Marian‚Äôs coach Robert Davis said. ‚ÄúThey had a great season. The girls had a goal to go back, win state again, and finish in the top 10 at nationals.‚Äù

Marian placed 13th at the national high school tournament last year and will return with hopes of cracking the top 10 this time around.

Locally, Kearney placed fifth with a team score of 700. North Platte junior Allie Jones tied for fifth individually, joining a handful of area golfers who finished inside the top 25.

snippet.title: UNL researchers unveil innovative irrigation device prototype
snippet.description:
Researchers from the University of Nebraska-Lincoln (UNL) Extension have unveiled a prototype device that could potentially save farmers thousands of dollars in irrigation costs. The team, led by Dr. Xin Qiao, an irrigation management specialist, has been developing the project for over two years and recently showcased it to the public at Husker Harvest Days.

Dr. Qiao explained that the inspiration for the device came from observing other self-powered valve products. "So the idea came from...a valve product [that] can generate power kind of by itself, with actuators. So we were thinking this can be used for irrigation equipment" he said.

snippet.title: Drone technology takes center stage at Husker Harvest Days
snippet.description:
Husker Harvest Days launched on Tuesday, featuring a bustling array of vendors, food and for the first time, a designated 'Drone zone'. Austin Leuth from Red Solutions, who helped give demonstrations at the Drone Zone, noted the growing interest in drone technology among attendees.

"Drones have been around. However I think the adoption or the acceptability of drones is increasing. There might be a day in our near future that you'll see a drone in every farm right now," said Leuth. He showcased the HD580 drone, designed for spraying but capable of using attachments like a spreader.

Leuth emphasized the importance of embracing technology, stating, "I think it takes the right person not to be scared of technology, be innovative. But you don't want to wait. The longer you wait, you're going to be behind. I think the technology is there. The changes today aren't going to be those peaks and valleys, it's going to be more of a plateau."

snippet.title: Nebraska Sweeps Washington to Stay Undefeated
snippet.description:
The No. 1 Nebraska volleyball team posted a 25-14, 25-18, 25-16 sweep of Washington on Friday in front of a crowd of 8,769 at John Cook Arena at the Bob Devaney Sports Center. 
 
The Huskers improved to 15-0 (5-0 Big Ten) with their 53rd straight home win. Washington fell to 7-8 (2-3 Big Ten). 
 
Harper Murray had a match-high 12 kills and hit .407 with seven digs and three blocks. Andi Jackson had 10 kills and hit .562 with two blocks, and Virginia Adriano had nine kills and a pair of blocks. Rebekah Allick and Taylor Landfair each had seven kills. Allick posted eight blocks and Landfair had four, as the Huskers finished with 10 as a team. 
 
Bergen Reilly put up 34 assists and nine digs. Olivia Mauch led the Big Red with 12 digs. Laney Choboy added six. 
 
Nebraska had a strong serving night with six aces and just one error. Mauch had two of the aces, while Reilly, Adriano, Murray and Teraya Sigler all had one. 
 
The Huskers hit .307 and held the Huskies to .147.
 
Nebraska has played 10 straight sets without allowing an opponent to reach 20 points. 

News release from Husker athletics

snippet.title: Huskers Dominate Houston Christian, Emphasize Return to the Standard as They Start Big 10 Play
snippet.description:
Nebraska didn‚Äôt just win on Saturday, the Huskers sent a message about the standard they expect to uphold.

The Huskers rolled Houston Christian 59-7 at Memorial Stadium, improving to 3-0 for the second straight year. It marked Nebraska‚Äôs ninth straight non-conference victory, each time holding opponents under 20 points.

‚ÄúWe haven‚Äôt played the caliber teams we‚Äôre going to play,‚Äù head coach Matt Rhule said. ‚ÄúBut all you can do is measure yourself against where you are and the standards that you have. To be 3-0 and dominate the two teams we‚Äôre supposed to dominate, that‚Äôs all I can ask of the guys.‚Äù

The defense again set the tone. Nebraska has now held three straight opponents under 100 yards passing for the first time since 1990. Offensively, the Huskers have scored 50 or more points in consecutive games for the first time since 2007, and posted 500-plus yards of offense in back-to-back weeks for the first time since 2021.

Quarterback Dylan Raiola kept the offense sharp, throwing for 222 yards and two touchdowns in one half of action. With the performance, Raiola moved into the top 10 on Nebraska‚Äôs career passing list.

‚ÄúOverall understanding of the game, just the leadership part of it, trusting my guys to make plays, ready for the challenge,‚Äù Raiola said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôll be full force coming in here on Saturday next week.‚Äù

Wide receiver Dane Key, a transfer from Kentucky, continued to make an immediate impact. He caught four passes for 104 yards and a touchdown, his third score in as many games. With the performance, he surpassed 2,000 career receiving yards, becoming just the eighth active FBS player to reach that mark.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm super excited that was accomplished today,‚Äù Key said. ‚ÄúBut that‚Äôs in the past now, so I just have to keep going.‚Äù

The Huskers will now turn their focus to Big Ten play, where the challenge escalates quickly. No. 23 Michigan visits Memorial Stadium next Saturday, Nebraska‚Äôs first ranked opponent of the season.

#Huskers #cornhuskers #huskerfootball #dylanraiola #danekey #nebraskafootball #nebraskafb #ncaafootball #mattrhule

snippet.title: Renewed push for passenger rail expansion in NE
snippet.description:
Trains are once again a topic of discussion in Grand Island as State Senator Margo Juarez leads a renewed push for expanding passenger rail across Nebraska. Juarez is touring the state, hosting town halls to advocate for legislation promoting passenger rail.

"We're so car centric in this state, and I think that it would be better to have some options," said Juarez. She is working on Legislative Resolution 203, which proposes an interim study on rail infrastructure in the state. Juarez emphasized the need for a proper rail planning study, noting that one has not been conducted in nearly 20 years. She said she envisions a future with safer, cheaper, and more convenient transportation options, including daytime Amtrak service, additional stops and special service cars for events like football and volleyball games.

"I even have this dream of possibly attracting even more future talent to serve in the legislature like myself," said Juarez. "If people realize that they can have easier transportation to Lincoln instead of driving all the time."

Read more: https://nebraska.tv/news/local/renewed-push-for-passenger-rail-expansion-in-nebraska#

snippet.title: Huskers Refocuses After Loss to Minnesota for a Tough Northwestern Big Ten Match Up
snippet.description:
Nebraska returned to the practice field this week intent on correcting the mistakes that led to its loss at Minnesota, with coaches and players echoing a unified message: accountability and improvement must come immediately if the Huskers want to become bowl eligible.

Head coach Matt Rhule‚Äôs message, coordinators and players said, was clear and received. The responsibility for the performance ‚Äî and the response ‚Äî is on them.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve just got to do better. We‚Äôve got to practice better, we‚Äôve got to prepare better, and we‚Äôve got to go play better,‚Äù offensive coordinator Dana Holgorsen said Tuesday. ‚ÄúIt starts with me. I‚Äôm responsible for what the offensive production is.‚Äù

Holgorsen stressed the need to establish the run and distribute the football more effectively after the offense struggled to push the ball downfield against Minnesota.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve got to get them in better plays that are quicker,‚Äù Holgorsen said. ‚ÄúFelt like we could push the ball down the field a little bit more against these guys, and it reared its ugly head again.‚Äù

On the defensive side, coordinator John Butler said takeaways and physicality must return to the forefront of the unit‚Äôs identity.

‚ÄúI have to do a better job of designing things and calling things that are going to do that,‚Äù Butler said. ‚ÄúThe takeaways will come as we get that accomplished.‚Äù

Butler acknowledged that Minnesota‚Äôs 70-yard touchdown run early in the game altered his approach more than it should have.

‚ÄúThat probably affected me more than it should, and it shouldn‚Äôt,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúEvery play has its own life. I‚Äôve got to stick to the plan and say regardless of what happened on the previous play, we‚Äôve still got to approach the game with an aggressive mentality.‚Äù

Players said they felt the same urgency from the coaching staff ‚Äî and from each other.

‚ÄúJust as a team, just playing hard and not just taking punches and not swinging back,‚Äù quarterback Dylan Raiola said. ‚ÄúThat just goes back to having pride for our university and for this football team.‚Äù

Nebraska (and its 15th-ranked rushing defense in the conference) will be tested immediately against Northwestern, which enters the week ranked sixth in the Big Ten in rushing offense. Players said they expect a fight up front and know the game plan is simple.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve just got to fight. We‚Äôve just got to do our job,‚Äù tight end Luke Lindenmeyer said. ‚ÄúIt sucks that we had to have a loss to have motivation to get back to that, but that‚Äôs what it took. This week we‚Äôre getting back to who we are.‚Äù

Injury Update

Right guard Rocco Spindler, who has started every game this season, returned to practice Tuesday after suffering a gruesome broken finger against Minnesota that required weekend surgery. He practiced with a cast, and teammates said his effort set the tone.

‚ÄúIf he can get up and practice and be on pace to play against Northwestern, there‚Äôs no reason that we can‚Äôt match that energy,‚Äù tight end Luke Lindemeyer said.

Nebraska hosts Northwestern on Saturday with kickoff at 11 AM CST as it continues its push for bowl eligibility.


#Huskers #cornhuskers #huskerfootball #dylanraiola #lukelindenmeyer #emmettjohnson #nebraskafootball #nebraskafb #ncaafootball

snippet.title: Huskers Football Ranked in AP Top 25,  Next a Big Ten Showdown with  Minnesota
snippet.description:
Nebraska football returned to the AP Top 25 this week, checking in at No. 25, just one spot ahead of No. 24 Cincinnati, a team the Huskers defeated in their season opener.

As Nebraska prepares to face Minnesota Friday night, head coach Matt Rhule said he‚Äôs proud of the growth his team has shown since Week 1 and is focused on building momentum toward a 6-1 record.

‚ÄúFor us, if we go out there and we‚Äôre minus three, then we are who we were two or three years ago,‚Äù Rhule said. ‚ÄúWe shouldn‚Äôt be that. We‚Äôre better, so we should just not give the game away and try to win the close games.‚Äù

Rhule also addressed rumors linking him to Penn State, emphasizing his commitment to Nebraska. ‚ÄúBut this is what happens when you win. I‚Äôve dealt with it at Temple and Baylor. I‚Äôm not going to talk about my contract here. I‚Äôm going to talk about the team. Players all across the country want to come here. We have the best facilities. We have elite fans. I‚Äôm really happy here and excited to get going this week on Minnesota.‚Äù

Nebraska enters the matchup 5-1 overall and 2-1 in Big Ten play. Minnesota is 4-2 overall, also 2-1 in conference play. A win would mark Nebraska‚Äôs first back-to-back road victories since 2006. The Huskers will face a Gophers team that has beaten Nebraska in five straight meetings and ranks among the nation‚Äôs best in turnover margin ‚Äî a key focus after Nebraska finished minus-three against Maryland.

Defensively, Nebraska remains one of the nation‚Äôs best, ranking first in passing defense and 14th overall, while quarterback Dylan Raiola leads an offense averaging more than 40 points per game, 11th nationally. Rhule stressed the need for the team to play complimentary football and close out games after allowing late comebacks in recent weeks.

The Huskers will wear all white Friday night in Minnesota as part of a joint breast cancer awareness initiative with the Gophers. On the injury front, defensive back Malcolm Hartzog remains questionable after missing the last couple of games with a lower-body injury.

Nebraska‚Äôs rise into the AP Top 25 marks consecutive years in the poll for the first time since 2016.

snippet.title: Nebraska Volleyball Faces Tough Road Test at No. 11 Wisconsin Friday and Home to Oregon Sunday
snippet.description:
Nebraska volleyball continues to roll through the 2025 season, entering the weekend 20-0 overall and 10-0 in Big Ten play. The nation‚Äôs No. 1 team has already collected seven wins over ranked opponents, including victories against Pittsburgh, Stanford, Penn State, and Creighton.

The toughest challenge yet may await Friday night when Nebraska travels to Madison to face No. 11 Wisconsin ‚Äî a rivalry matchup with plenty of history. Since the teams first met in 2011, Wisconsin holds a slim 13-12 edge over the Huskers. The Badgers also defeated Nebraska in the 2021 NCAA Championship match to capture their first national title.

Nebraska has had the upper hand more recently, sweeping Wisconsin twice in the 2024 regular season, followed by a regional final victory in Lincoln to advance to the NCAA semifinals.

Head coach Dani Busboom Kelly said the Badgers‚Äô talent makes them a complete test. ‚ÄúThey have one of the best lefts in the country and one of the best middles,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre definitely going to be motivated to beat us. The whole matchup is challenging.‚Äù

Senior Rebekah Allick said the team embraces the moment. ‚ÄúWe live for high-level volleyball,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúBeing ranked No. 1 is cool, but it doesn‚Äôt determine who wins Saturday night.‚Äù

Setter Bergen Reilly added that Nebraska‚Äôs competitiveness in practice keeps the group sharp heading into late October.

After Friday‚Äôs road trip, Nebraska returns home to host Oregon on Sunday afternoon. Busboom Kelly expects that quick turnaround to be another test. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs going to be a huge challenge coming off a night game on the road and facing a confident Oregon team,‚Äù she said.

Nebraska continues to dominate not just on the court, but in attendance. The Huskers lead the nation in home attendance and rank second when factoring in crowds for their road matches ‚Äî meaning Nebraska volleyball owns both the No. 1 and No. 2 spots in national attendance.

Busboom Kelly said she appreciates how Big Red fans travel, but expects a true road test in Madison. ‚ÄúWisconsin fans love their volleyball too,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôll be a wild environment.‚Äù

snippet.title: Bergen Reilly and Rebekah Allick Collect Big Ten Weekly Honors
snippet.description:
Lincoln, NEB ‚Äî Press Release from Nebraska Athletics-

Nebraska volleyball's Bergen Reilly and Rebekah Allick earned Big Ten weekly conference awards on Monday. Reilly was named Big Ten Co-Setter of the Week, while Allick was named Big Ten Defensive Player of the Week.

Reilly earned her 12th career Big Ten Setter of the Week accolade and third of the season. Allick was named Big Ten Defensive Player of the Week for the fourth time in her career and second time this season.

Reilly set the Huskers to another outstanding weekend of offensive performances. The Huskers hit a combined .372 in sweeps at No. 11 Wisconsin and vs. Oregon with Reilly averaging 10.67 assists per set and 2.17 digs per set. She also recorded five kills and five blocks.

At Wisconsin, Reilly had 38 assists, eight digs, four blocks and three kills as the Huskers hit .349 against the second-best defensive team in the Big Ten. It was the highest hitting percentage allowed by Wisconsin at the UW Field House since 2012. Against Oregon, the junior setter finished with 26 assists, five digs, two kills and a block as Nebraska hit .405, its third-best efficiency of the season.

For the season, Reilly has the Huskers on school-record pace with a .339 hitting percentage, which leads the nation. The Huskers have hit over .300 in 13 straight matches, a school record in the rally-scoring era (2001-present).

Allick totaled 11 blocks (1.83 per set) in Nebraska's two victories. She added 2.00 kills per set on a .500 hitting percentage as well.

The senior middle blocker had six blocks at Wisconsin to help the top-ranked Huskers stifle the nation's No. 2-ranked offense to a .175 hitting percentage. She added seven kills on .538 hitting. Against Oregon on Sunday, Allick had five blocks (one solo) with five kills on .444 hitting.

Allick became the fifth Husker in the rally-scoring era to surpass 500 career blocks on Sunday, as she now has 502.

#nebraskavolleyball #cornhuskers #huskers

snippet.title: Nebraska Football's Team Reaction to Punter Archie Wilson's Viral Moment
snippet.description:
Nebraska football held its final preseason scrimmage Saturday behind closed doors, while the Husker volleyball team hosted its annual alumni match. Both programs are set to provide updates later Saturday evening.

Before the scrimmage, sophomore quarterback Dylan Raiola spoke with the media Friday in a wide-ranging session. Among the topics was punter Archie Wilson, whose emotional press conference earlier this month went viral and drew national attention.

Raiola said the team was deeply moved by Wilson‚Äôs story.

‚ÄúThey showed the clip in the team meeting, and I got chicken skin seeing that,‚Äù Raiola said. ‚ÄúI remember when Archie came on his visit with his parents from Australia. They were explaining the travel it took to get here, and I couldn‚Äôt really believe it. I think he deserves all the praise he‚Äôs getting.‚Äù

Wilson, who came to Lincoln from Melbourne, has had to adjust to more than football. From learning American terminology to punting in yards instead of meters, Raiola said the transition hasn‚Äôt been easy.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs kind of just been plopped down in the middle of the United States and had to grow up quick,‚Äù Raiola said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve seen nothing but that from him. The guys have surrounded him with love and open arms.‚Äù

Wilson‚Äôs unique skillset has also impressed his teammates. Known for his ability to punt with both legs, Raiola said Wilson can roll right or left before striking the ball ‚Äî a versatility that could become a weapon this season.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôll be pretty cool to see ‚Äî hopefully not too much ‚Äî but to see him punt in games,‚Äù Raiola added.

Wilson‚Äôs story has resonated beyond the locker room. Fans across Nebraska, particularly on social media, embraced him as part of the community.

‚ÄúHe has a family here,‚Äù Raiola said. ‚ÄúAnd when you feel good, you play good.‚Äù

Now one of only two state fairgrounds in the country with a hotel directly on-site, joining the New York State Fairgrounds, it offers guests a more personal, convenient experience during the 156th Nebraska State Fair.

‚ÄúJust the firsthand look, the oversight that you would get to see looking out your balcony in the morning and seeing the fair kind of come to life each day,‚Äù said Glock, who described the experience for guests staying at the new on-site hotel during the 156th Nebraska State Fair. snippet.title: NTV Sports Extra: Week 1 August 29th, 2025
ICE Detention facility 'Cornhusker Clink' confirmed
snippet.description:
Governor Pillen announced that the Department of Homeland Security is creating an ICE detention facility akin to 'Alligator Alcatraz' in McCook. The facility would replace the existing Work Ethic Camp detention facility and would increase its capacity from 200 beds to around 300. Pillen called the move a triumph for border security in the U.S.

"We're simply doing our part to get these people the heck out of get them off of our streets, get them out of our communities and get them the heck out of here," said Pillen.

U.S. Secretary of Homeland Security Kristi Noem said earlier this month that Nebraska was on her short list of places for additional ICE facilities, and said that they were looking for a place with proximity to an airport. On Noem's X account she already embraced the nickname of 'Cornhusker Clink' and shared a post about it. Pillen says that he doesn't know if men, women, or children would be detained in the facility, but said there wouldn't be any safety concerns.

"The security keeping us safe is the highest priority. I've told the mayor, 'If there's any hole, you call me, we will get it fixed,'" said Pillen.

Read more: https://nebraska.tv/news/local/pillen-confirms-ice-detention-facility-coming-to-mccook-sparking-protest-and-praise#

snippet.title: Huskers Volleyball Sweeps Cardinals to Stay Undefeated
snippet.description:
No. 1 Nebraska capped a perfect opening weekend with a sweep of No. 6 Stanford on Sunday at Pinnacle Bank Arena, finishing 2‚Äì0 at the AVCA First Serve Showcase.

They won 25-13, 25-19, 25-14 in front of a crowd of 15,734 at Pinnacle Bank Arena.

The Huskers (2-0) hit a blistering .385 and held the Cardinal (1-1) to .094 hitting. Allie Sczech earned her first start as a Husker and connected for 12 kills on .400 hitting. Rebekah Allick tallied 11 kills, five blocks and hit .600 to earn MVP honors in the match. Harper Murray contributed 10 kills and nine digs and hit .308.

Bergen Reilly had 36 assists, nine digs, four kills and three blocks. Laney Choboy and Olivia Mauch led the Big Red with 12 digs each.

NU had a 9-2 edge in blocks, 56-35 advantage in digs and 46-31 lead in kills.

Stanford got eight kills from Elia Rubin.

Nebraska opened the event by beating No. 3 Pittsburgh 3‚Äì1 on Friday before a second sellout saw the Huskers sweep Stanford in the first volleyball matches ever played at PBA.

Next up, Nebraska (2‚Äì0) heads to Nashville to face Lipscomb on Friday and Kentucky on Sunday.

snippet.title: Heritage of Resilience
snippet.description:
At 96 years old Lloyd Frandsen is still farming, still gardening, and still canning tomatoes.

He's the grandfather of Christina Houghtelling-Hudson a former Husker volleyball star who was the national volleyball player of the year in 2005 and a Husker Athletics hall of famer.

But its her impact she's having on current volleyball players, both at NU and across the area, that can be tied back to the inspiration she draws from her grandfather.

Giving back is something that Christina Houghtelling-Hudson was raised watching her family and friends do and today she is teaching high school volleyball players, even coming back to Cambridge and hosting a free clinic for young volleyball players in her hometown.

Read more: https://nebraska.tv/news/local/gingers-journey-heritage-of-resilience#

snippet.title: Nebraska Unveil Blackout Game as Raiola, Coaches Praise Offensive Growth
snippet.description:
Nebraska quarterback Dylan Raiola could not hide his excitement Friday as the Huskers unveiled new black alternate uniforms for their Nov. 1 matchup against USC at Memorial Stadium.

‚ÄúWe love them. The whole team loves them. We all love them,‚Äù Raiola said. ‚ÄúHope our fans come out to the USC game and rock their black. I think it‚Äôs something special.‚Äù

Beyond the uniforms, Raiola said his biggest growth entering year two as starting quarterback has been his command of the offense.

‚ÄúUnderstanding why we‚Äôre running a play, what we‚Äôre running it against, and what can beat it‚ÄîI feel comfortable right now,‚Äù Raiola said.

Offensive coordinator Dana Holgorsen praised Raiola‚Äôs progress, pointing to his leadership and poise.

‚ÄúHis leadership is outstanding. The play is fantastic,‚Äù Holgorsen said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs making throws I‚Äôve never seen before. He‚Äôs in a good spot and he‚Äôs ready for game day.‚Äù

Holgorsen added that the offense has shown more explosive moments this preseason than in previous years but emphasized the need for sustained drives. He said Saturday‚Äôs scrimmage will provide a better test in simulating game conditions.

‚ÄúWe do a nice job in drills and kind of three-and-out stuff, but we haven‚Äôt done a live scrimmage where it‚Äôs, ‚ÄòHey, eight minutes on the clock, can we go get a touchdown in the fourth quarter?‚Äô‚Äù Holgorsen said.

Offensive line coach Donovan Raiola, Dylan‚Äôs uncle, also pointed to the quarterback‚Äôs growing communication with the line in his second year.

‚ÄúThe comfort level they have on and off the field has really grown,‚Äù Raiola said.

Head coach Matt Rhule is expected to provide a full update after Saturday‚Äôs scrimmage, the final one before the Huskers begin game-week preparation.

snippet.title: Huskers Sweep Cal for Perfect Weekend
snippet.description:
Nebraska volleyball closed out a perfect weekend at the Bob Devaney Sports Center, sweeping Rice State on Friday and California on Sunday to improve to 6-0 under first-year head coach Danielle Buss.

The Huskers did not drop a set in either match, extending Buss‚Äôs undefeated start in Lincoln. Still, the coach said the team‚Äôs performance wasn‚Äôt flawless.

‚ÄúNot everybody gets to win. We always say it‚Äôs hard to win, and to win in that fashion against anybody is pretty impressive,‚Äù Buss said. ‚ÄúBut on Friday, we didn‚Äôt play our best. After watching the tape, we actually played worse than we thought. I was excited to see a sharper focus against Cal.‚Äù

That focus was highlighted by freshman setter Campbell Flynn, who made her debut Sunday. Buss praised Flynn for running an efficient offense in her first action.

‚ÄúShe came in cold, didn‚Äôt play Friday night, and I thought she was awesome,‚Äù Buss said. ‚ÄúShe ran a great offense, and she‚Äôs super confident out there.‚Äù

Flynn said playing in front of the Devaney Center crowd was a moment she won‚Äôt forget.

‚ÄúThe crowd was awesome, my team was awesome, and I had a really fun time,‚Äù Flynn said.

All-American middle blocker [player‚Äôs name if available] credited Flynn for setting the tone in the middle.

‚ÄúWhen Campbell came in, she was just firing the ball and did an awesome job getting it to the middle,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt was really easy to get hot from there.‚Äù

Nebraska now turns its attention to the Husker Invitational. The Huskers host Utah on Friday and Grand Canyon on Saturday before traveling to Omaha on Tuesday for a highly anticipated matchup with Creighton.

snippet.title: No. 21 Michigan Beats Nebraska 30-27: Highlights and Post Game Reaction
snippet.description:
In a tightly contested Big Ten opener, No. 21 Michigan edged Nebraska 30‚Äì27 on Saturday at Memorial Stadium in Lincoln. The Wolverines improved to 3‚Äì1 overall and 1‚Äì0 in conference play, while the Cornhuskers fell to 3‚Äì1 and 0‚Äì1 in the Big Ten. 

Michigan's offense was propelled by a dominant ground game, amassing 286 rushing yards. Running back Justice Haynes led the charge with 149 yards on 17 carries, including a 75-yard touchdown run. Freshman quarterback Bryce Underwood added 105 passing yards and a 37-yard touchdown run. Jordan Marshall contributed with a 54-yard touchdown run, marking his first significant play of the season. 
Maize n Brew

Defensively, the Wolverines were relentless, recording seven sacks and 10 tackles for loss. Linebacker Cole Sullivan had a standout performance with an interception, a sack, and six tackles. True freshman safety Jayden Sanders stepped up in the absence of Zeke Berry, recording eight tackles and solid coverage on crucial third downs. 
Maize n Brew

Nebraska's quarterback Dylan Raiola threw for 308 yards and three touchdowns, connecting with Jacory Barney Jr. for two scores. Running back Emmett Johnson added 67 rushing yards, but the Huskers' offense struggled to establish a consistent ground game, totaling just 43 rushing yards. 
Wikipedia

The game featured dramatic momentum swings. After trailing 10‚Äì0, Nebraska rallied to tie the game at 17‚Äì17 by halftime, highlighted by a 52-yard Hail Mary touchdown pass from Raiola to Barney Jr. However, Michigan's second-half scoring, including a 56-yard field goal and a 54-yard touchdown run, proved decisive. 

Michigan's victory extended its winning streak against Nebraska to five games and improved its all-time series lead to 9‚Äì4‚Äì1. The Wolverines also secured their sixth consecutive win in a Big Ten opener. 
University of Michigan Athletics

Nebraska will look to rebound in its next conference matchup, aiming to build on the resilience shown in a hard-fought game against a ranked opponent.

#Huskers #cornhuskers #huskerfootball #dylanraiola #lukelindenmeyer #emmettjohnson #nebraskafootball #nebraskafb #ncaafootball

snippet.title: Middles lead top ranked Huskers past Maryland for third straight sweep
snippet.description:
Nebraska wasted little time in dispatching another Big Ten opponent. The No. 1 Huskers improved to 12-0 and 2-0 in Big Ten conference play Saturday night with a sweep of Maryland, their third consecutive straight-set victory.

Nebraska‚Äôs middle blockers stole the spotlight. Senior captain Rebekah Allick delivered 13 kills on 17 swings and added six blocks, while fellow captain Andi Jackson posted nine kills on 10 attempts along with five blocks.

‚ÄúAs a middle, you dream about games like this,‚Äù Allick said. ‚ÄúIt just makes Monday through Friday worth it.‚Äù

The Huskers identified Maryland‚Äôs blocking weaknesses in the middle and repeatedly took advantage of one-on-one matchups. ‚ÄúWe really wanted to take advantage of that one-on-one, and it was pretty guaranteed to be there,‚Äù Jackson said.

Allick‚Äôs performance also came with milestones. She moved into the program‚Äôs top five for total blocks in the rally-scoring era and finished with a career-high .800 hitting percentage.

‚ÄúThe thing about Nebraska volleyball is it‚Äôs full of giants,‚Äù Allick said. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt really do it for the accolades. You do it because you love the sport.‚Äù

Head coach Dani Busboom Kelly praised her middles for carrying out the game plan. ‚ÄúThey both had huge nights,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúExecuting the game plan, the middles took advantage, and that was huge.‚Äù

The Huskers have not dropped a set since a three-match stretch ago against Creighton. They remain undefeated under Busboom Kelly and now turn to their first road test outside Nebraska since August.

Nebraska will visit No. 15 Penn State on Oct. 3, with first serve set for 7 p.m.

snippet.title: Coach Rhule Tells Huskers to Stay The Course After Michigan Loss
snippet.description:
Nebraska head coach Matt Rhule said he was encouraged by his team‚Äôs effort in Saturday‚Äôs 30-27 loss to Michigan, stressing that his players must stay disciplined during their bye week.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a very calculated response ‚Äî not to overreact, not to underreact, but just to be very disciplined in the way that we see things,‚Äù Rhule said Monday. ‚ÄúWhat I‚Äôve asked our guys not to do is settle for the narrative of how we‚Äôre just a couple plays away. That‚Äôs a deadly, deadly thing when you start saying things like that.‚Äù

The Wolverines rushed for 286 yards, with three long runs accounting for more than half of that total. Rhule said those breakdowns were ‚Äúvery self-inflicted wounds.‚Äù

‚ÄúEverybody can play better,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs really important that we take ownership, but stay very neutral.‚Äù

Offensively, Nebraska allowed seven sacks of quarterback Dylan Raiola. Rhule said protection issues stemmed from lack of width in the pocket, but he praised Raiola‚Äôs overall play.

‚ÄúI think Dylan‚Äôs playing quarterback at a really high level right now,‚Äù Rhule said.

Despite the loss, Rhule pointed to improvements in special teams and passing defense and said confidence in the program remains high.

Rhule also reported no major injuries out of the Michigan game, calling it ‚Äújust bumps and bruises.‚Äù With the bye week ahead, the Huskers conducted a film study on Sunday, will practice Tuesday through Thursday, and then allow the coaching staff to hit the recruiting trail before returning to prepare for Michigan State.

It was announced on Monday that the Michigan State game will be a 3 PM CST kickoff at Memorial Stadium on Oct 4th.

snippet.description:
Maroon 5 is set to perform in Lincoln on October 28 at the Pinnacle Bank Arena as part of their "Love is Like" tour. Front man Adam Levine and lead guitarist James Valentine shared insights about their latest album and personal reflections in a recent interview.

Levine described the creative process behind the album as a "DaVinci code thing," explaining, "I have to go back, cause it's so stream of consciousness a lot of the times, I'll throw a lot of things out there and try to make sense of it and put in the song. I'll go back and be like 'oh California like that also sounds like a very specific time in my life but I set out to write about that experience when I wrote the song.'"

snippet.title: UNK no longer selling alcohol at football games this season
snippet.description:
The University of Nebraska - Kearney will no longer be selling alcohol at games this season.

Originally, the school planned to sell alcohol at all football games this year, but earlier today, UNK said they would not be moving forward with that decision.

‚ÄúUNK has decided not to move forward with alcohol sales at Loper football games this season," said UNK in an official statement. After careful review, insurance costs were cost-prohibitive for UNK and our concession vendor. We will revisit the concept in the offseason to evaluate options for future seasons.‚Äù

After the back and forth of announcing alcohol sales and no actual alcohol being sold in the first two games to now, some students believe the school wasn‚Äôt fully prepared.

snippet.title: Full John Cook Bronze Statue Ceremony + Media Scrum Interview with Dani Busboom Kelly and John Cook
snippet.description:
Speakers at the event included University of Nebraska President Jeffrey Gold, Nebraska Director of Athletics Troy Dannen, Nebraska Volleyball Head Coach Dani Busboom Kelly and Cook.
 
Overall, Cook spent 32 years as a college head coach - seven at Wisconsin and 25 at Nebraska.
 
Consistent excellence was a hallmark of Cook‚Äôs Nebraska teams. Since taking over the program in 2000, Cook guided the Huskers to four national championships, 12 NCAA Semifinals appearances, nine Big 12 titles and five Big Ten titles. He achieved a career record of 883-176 (.834), the fifth-best winning percentage all-time for a Division I volleyball coach. Cook's record of 722-103 at Nebraska was the best winning percentage (.875) for any DI program from 2000-24.
 
With Cook at the helm, Nebraska produced numerous individual honors, including five Olympians, a Honda-Broderick Cup winner, three AVCA Division I National Players of the Year, 72 AVCA All-Americans, three Academic All-Americans of the Year, 25 Academic All-Americans and 10 conference players of the year. Nebraska volleyball student-athletes combined for 88 all-conference awards and 155 academic all-conference honors in Cook's program.

snippet.title: Veterans and Young Huskers Shine vs. Akron
snippet.description:
Nebraska opened its home schedule with a record-setting performance Saturday night, routing Akron 68-0 at Memorial Stadium.

The 68 points were the Huskers‚Äô most in a game since scoring 73 against Idaho State in 2012. Nebraska piled up 728 yards of total offense, the eighth-highest mark in program history.

Junior tight end Luke Lindenmeyer highlighted the night with his first career touchdown ‚Äî and a marriage proposal at midfield after the game. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt really tell the whole team,‚Äù Lindenmeyer said. ‚ÄúCoach mentioned it yesterday, and then the whole team knew and was just standing there. It was awesome.‚Äù

He wasn‚Äôt the only first-time scorer. Redshirt freshman receiver Quinn Clark caught a 37-yard touchdown, and true freshman quarterback T.J. Lateef threw for 128 yards and rushed for his first career score in relief of Dylan Raiola. Raiola, the sophomore starter, threw for 364 yards and four touchdowns, completing a school-record 20 consecutive passes spanning two games.

On defense, freshman lineman Kade Pietrzak‚Äôs first career tackle resulted in a safety ‚Äî Nebraska‚Äôs first since last year‚Äôs opener.

Running back Emmett Johnson led the ground game with another 100+ yards rushing and three touchdowns (2 on the ground, 1 in the air). Transfer wide receiver Dane Key added his second touchdown in as many games.

The shutout was Nebraska‚Äôs first since the 2009 Holiday Bowl against Arizona. 

The Huskers improved to 2-0 and will host Houston Christian on Sept. 13.

Outside Linebackers Coach Phil Simpson breaks down what it takes to be a complete defender in today‚Äôs game. It‚Äôs not just about getting sacks ‚Äî it's about stopping the run, dropping into coverage, and being mentally locked in.

Development of Jordan Ochoa, both physically and mentally

Emphasis on versatility at the OLB position

Importance of being an every-down player ‚Äî not just a pass rusher

Updates on Dylan Rodgers, Willis McGahee IV, and others

snippet.title: Unbeaten Huskers Volleyball Stay Grounded as Big Ten Grind Continues
snippet.description:
Nebraska is deep into the dog days of the season, and middle blocker Andi Jackson says the grind is real. But despite the schedule, the Huskers remain perfect. Nebraska sits at 22-0 overall and 12-0 in Big Ten play, the lone unbeaten team left in Division I volleyball and a unanimous No. 1 in this week‚Äôs national polls.

Head coach Dani Busboom Kelly said she isn‚Äôt letting her team get comfortable.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been focused on getting better here and there, competing with each other,‚Äù Busboom Kelly said. ‚ÄúOur players understand how thin the line is this year. There are players all over the country who can take over matches and get hot, and you can find yourself in a tough situation really quick in our sport.‚Äù

Nebraska survived close opening sets at a ranked Wisconsin and at home against Oregon before pulling away. Jackson said the team knew their first-set defense wasn‚Äôt up to standard but responded the right way.

‚ÄúEveryone knows our first-set defense wasn‚Äôt our best ever,‚Äù Jackson said. ‚ÄúAdjusting in the second and third sets, and then at Wisconsin, we handled things there. It felt so smooth. Our team felt so connected on the court.‚Äù

Freshman outside hitter Virginia Adriano continues to adjust to Big Ten volleyball, saying the pace and intensity are unlike anything she experienced in Italy.

‚ÄúWhen I first got here, I didn‚Äôt really know a lot about other teams or the rivalries,‚Äù Adriano said. ‚ÄúOnce I understood Texas, Wisconsin, Penn State ‚Äî great atmospheres, loud gyms ‚Äî it‚Äôs always cool to play in places like that.‚Äù

Nebraska‚Äôs next two matches come against Illinois on Nov. 6 at the Devaney Center, followed by a road test at No. 22 Minnesota on Nov. 8. Busboom Kelly said Illinois features a setter she competed against during her time at Louisville, and Minnesota remains dangerous despite early injuries.

‚ÄúIllinois has a setter I played against for two years at Florida State ‚Äî she‚Äôs a baller,‚Äù Busboom Kelly said. ‚ÄúMinnesota had the injury bug early on, but they‚Äôre finding ways to win and stay in the top 25. They have one of the best outsides in the country and a really good young setter. It‚Äôs always hard to play at the Pav.‚Äù

Nebraska also brought home individual honors this week. Middle blocker Rebekah Allick was named Big Ten Defensive Player of the Week (third this season, twelfth in career), and setter Bergen Reilly earned Co-Setter of the Week (second this season, fourth in career). Busboom Kelly credited their commitment to the game plan.

‚ÄúThey‚Äôre not doing anything special,‚Äù Busboom Kelly said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre just playing inside the game plan and doing what‚Äôs needed for this team to stay undefeated.‚Äù

#HuskerVB #GBR #NebraskaVolleyball #bergenreilly #rebekahallick #HuskerSports
